speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: There are seven minutes remaining in questions and comments to the hon. member for Ontario. The hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood had the floor.

Mr. Speaker, just a short preamble of my comments before we went into Question Period.
I indicated parts of the member's speech where I quite frankly agreed with some of the statements he had made.
As I pointed out, we are not here just to assist those who are advantaged. We are also challenged and it is our primary responsibility on this side of the House to speak for those people who are going through difficult times in all communities across Canada where there are people unemployed.
There is room for the Government of Canada to do more work with the 1.7 million entrepreneurs in this country. The greatest hope for job creation lies within that sector of the economy. I believe that with low interest rates and low inflation, it improves their position to participate in bringing people off the welfare and unemployment insurance rolls.
This is what I would like to ask the member. Does he not share the view of many that there is a real problem with confidence in that particular sector of our economy, namely the small and medium-sized entrepreneur? We are always being challenged here to present ideas. Does he not think that it would be a good idea to review the standing committee that put forward employment opportunities for the 1980s? This report was produced in 1982, I believe. The Minister of State for Finance and Privatization was part of that committee. There are 186 ideas within this report that the government could review or pick and choose. They are all ideas on how to put Canadians back to work.
What is wrong with reviewing that? What is wrong with taking some of these ideas and using them to lever the entrepreneurship of this country so that they can be motivated to take a chance on the 1.5 million Canadians who are out of work? If each company hired one person in the next 60 days we would have a much better economy on our hands and we would reduce that $35 billion to $40 billion draw which is all taxpayers' money. It would even give us some opportunity or option to reduce taxes.
Why does the government not see if it can use that force to put Canadians back to work?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the questions from the member for Broadview-Greenwood.
The member is certainly correct in talking about low inflation and low interest rates being of benefit to the small business community and the entrepreneur. He should also of course agree that low inflation and low interest rates are also significant benefits to the unemployed and those on fixed incomes, whether they are senior citizens or others. Inflation is the worse curse that they face. There are some real positive things and I think the member has acknowledged some of that in his comments.
I am sorry I am not personally familiar with this 1982 report. I guess the report that the member refers to talks about many opportunities. From 1982 to 1992, if I heard the minister correctly today, there are over 2 million more people employed in the work force. That is not to say that we should be satisfied at that level. I am sure that specific ideas could come out of that. This could be combined with some of the ideas that are in the budget this year such as improvements to accessing funds for small businesses and the re-regulation of the financial industry to allow entrepreneurs access to funds. There are many things that can be done.
In conjunction with the member, I look forward to the government coming forward and saying: "Look at item number 10 in that proposal and let's do it". It could also be number 11 or number 12.1 suspect that many of them have already been implemented.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Ontario in his speech this morning criticized the remarks of my colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River who pointed out that the policies of this Conservative government had forced tax increases on the municipalities and the provinces. The hon. member for Ontario said that if municipalities had increased taxes then that was their doing and we should condemn them and not the federal government.
I want to ask the hon. member this. Does he not realize that when his government, the Conservative government, cut unemployment insurance benefits, as it did a few years ago in Bill C-21, and when it made it more difficult to qualify for unemployment insurance and when it shortened the benefit period and made other
June 5, 1992

cuts, that it was in fact shifting the burden of the unemployed to a great extent to the municipalities in Ontario and to the province? If you have a large number of people who are unemployed, and they do not have unemployment insurance, there is no place else they can go to keep them alive but to the welfare system. The welfare system is financed in Ontario by the municipalities with the help of the province. Either the member did not know what he was voting for when he voted for Bill C-21 a few years ago or he did it and is now concealing the fact. The fact of the matters is that thousands of people who would have been eligible for unemployment insurance and covered by the federal program are not now covered by that federal program. Since we do not believe in letting people starve to death the only recourse for those people is to go to the municipalities.
I was on the committee that studied that bill. We went to Sudbury, Ottawa, and Toronto. Every municipality said: "Do not do that because you are going to increase our tax burden. You are going to put a big burden on us to take care of the unemployed".
I ask the hon. member how he can say that the policies of his government were not responsible for that enormous shift to those municipalities in Ontario for the unemployed? Nobody else can take care of them if they do not have unemployment insurance.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The hon. member has one minute to answer that question.

Mr. Speaker, I could use the whole day.
The fact of the matter is that in the unemployment insurance scheme the higher the unemployment insurance rate in a particular region, the higher the benefit time available to individuals. Throughout Ontario there are tremendous programs through unemployment insurance. These include many training funds which help keep people off the welfare rolls.
It was not the federal government that increased the rate of payment to welfare recipients by 28 per cent. I should point out, contrary to what the member says, that it is the federal government that helps fund the program with 50 per cent of the dollars. It is the provincial government that spends it willy-nilly as though there are no controls required.
Supply
There is a substantial difference in outlook between me and the member. I guess I would take our approach as being a far more constructive approach to the issue of taxation in Ontario.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak to the motion of the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River. I commend him and his caucus for putting forward this motion.
The motion is:
That this House condemns the government for its negligence
toward the worst social and economic difficulties faced by residents
of Ontario in modern times.
We all know the signs of trouble in Ontario, as well as in other parts of this country. Some previous speakers have given some of the statistics on the matter. Some speakers following me from all sides will quote statistics. Therefore, I do not wish to go heavily into the statistics of the trouble signs. The main one is the increase in unemployed as a percentage to 11.2 per cent. This is one of the very highest rates that we have had in my lifetime since I was a boy during the Depression.
Worse than that, factories have been closed and even dismantled at twice the rate they were during the last recession in 1981-82. Those jobs are not going to return if good times-as they are called-return. They are gone. The factories are gone. They have been dismantled. There is a little bit of employment among some of my friends in the millwright union for dismantling factories, but it is not what they would rather do. They would rather be building factories.
In Toronto, on College Street where I live, there are homeless and there are beggars. People come to my office who have been quite demoralized by experiencing the downturn in the economy as it has affected them, their families and their friends.
We have seen a youth riot in Toronto. We have seen gang fights and general signs of considerably demoralized youth. This includes the drop-out rate in the high schools.
There are some things that can be done, even by the provincial government, which the Ontario government is trying to do. It has borrowed money to restart some jobs. For example, there is highway construction and the building of 20,000 units of non-profit housing. The president of local 183 told me a couple of weeks ago how

Supply
pleased he is that at least 5,000 of the 12,000 members of his union are working.
He is very pleased to see 50 construction cranes around the city. He says that if it were not for the non-profit housing program of the Ontario government hardly any of that would be happening.
There are 20,000 day care spaces to be opened under the government's program. The government has also taken a risk, a well considered one and I hope it will be a successful one, to prevent the Algoma Steel mill in Sault Ste. Marie from closing. When the crisis broke the provincial government moved in quickly and organized a task force including all stakeholders: the community, the union, the company, the banks, the provincial government and the federal government.
I must commend the federal government because, although it delayed long enough to cause considerable worry, it nevertheless joined with the Ontario government in a program to subsidize older workers' early retirement so that the people of Sault Ste. Marie do not lose all their young men and women by forcing them to leave Sault Ste. Marie to find work.
However, I do not want to dwell on the remedial programs that may be used, that may not be used, that should be used and so on. I want to deal with a large fundamental problem that needs federal action, which is the impact of the free trade agreement and of the proposed North American free trade agreement in terms of destroying jobs.
The federal government must cancel the existing agreement and cease negotiations on the present North American agreement until it can be fundamentally reorganized along different lines so that it does not put all the burden of change on working people.
I want to quote from a recent report of the city of Toronto's economic development committee to the city council on the-
Communist.

The hon. gentleman across calls Mayor Rowlands and various other people communists. I will leave it to him to sort it out with them.
This is a report of the city of Toronto. It will be considered in a couple of weeks at a meeting of the city's committee on this issue. It concerns the impact of trade liberalization on the city of Toronto.
There is not enough time to go through the whole report because it is a very detailed report based on many other documentary surveys. For example, it points out that there has been a great shift of head offices from Ontario to the United States. Pillsbury has moved and Avis has terminated 16 of its head office positions. Head offices in the city of Toronto experienced a 16.2 per cent drop in employment from 1989, following the free trade agreement, to 1991, a loss of 7,254 jobs. This is happening in the head offices of our country.
Another segment of industry that has been very hard hit is the food processing industry. There is a great deal of food processing in and close to the city of Toronto and metro Toronto, though not as much as there was. In the period from 1989 to 1991 the food processing industry lost 21.4 per cent of its jobs in the city of Toronto and 8.6 per cent in metropolitan Toronto as a whole.
Many of those industries moved to the United States, partly as a consequence of a wave of mergers and American takeovers of industries like UNICO which then either shut them down or seriously reduced them.
The Ontario Food Processors' Association which hopefully supported the free trade agreement in 1988 is now pointing out that although the federal government promised transitional assistance-it was recognized there would have to be transitions in the industry and the federal government promised transitional assistance to those industries negatively affected- this assistance has not been forthcoming, at least not so far as the association is concerned.
The United Food and Commercial Workers Union is of the opinion that the free trade agreement has not presented the industry with the open markets of the United States that were promised. This is widely understood. It has even been acknowledged by some of the people who helped to negotiate the agreement, such as Mr. Ritchie, that the Americans have not kept their side of the bargain and it looks as if they are going to be less
June 5, 1992

willing to keep their side of the bargain. This has had a very serious effect on this industry.
The union also wants to know what has happened to the promised restructuring and retraining assistance that was promised by the Prime Minister during the last election.
One of the sections of the city planning department, the Workers' Information and Action Centre, has pointed out that Kellogg shut down its Etobicoke plant in June 1991 laying off 380 workers. VS Services of Toronto announced in its annual meeting in February that 1991 was the worst year for the food processing industry in its history. It cited the effect of the free trade agreement on closings as one of the causes.
Nobody pretends there has not been a recession around the world. However, the rate of job loss in manufacturing in Canada has been 23 per cent over the last three years and the rate of job loss in the United States for the same period has been only 6 per cent. We have lost jobs at four times the rate of the United States.
If you want to know why read the Conference Board report.
That is largely because of American takeovers and American ownership, and their preference for shutting down plants, such as Inglis in my riding.
Read the facts.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: There will be an opportunity to ask the hon. member questions after his speech. I would like to hear it and I hope other members will give him the opportunity.

In the film, video, and audio industry from 1989 to 1991 there was a 7.7 per cent drop in employment in the city of Toronto and a 3.6 per cent drop in metro as a whole.
In the radio and TV stations there was an 18.4 per cent drop from 1989 to 1991 in Toronto, and a 9.8 per cent drop in metro as a whole. There are many industries that are not listed here. Only a few of the key ones were picked for emphasis.
In the publishing industry other than newspaper publishing, newspapers seem to have done well, there was an 11 per cent drop in employment from 1989 to 1991 in the city of Toronto and 5.5 per cent in metro as a whole.
Supply
Obviously the city of Toronto, being the centre of many of these industries, has felt a greater impact than metro as a whole.
The Canadian Printing Industry Association has estimated that 3,000 jobs were lost across Canada which were directly attributable to the free trade agreement. It maintains that the industry's current unemployment rate in metro is 14 per cent following a loss of 3,700 jobs. It also points out that the annual trade deficit in printed products has jumped by 214 per cent since 1989. That is a very big jump in the trade deficit in print between Canada and the United States over two years, to the disadvantage of Canada.
It went from $106 million to $331 million and it expects that with an annual growth rate this deficit will reach $485 million by the end of this year. This is the industry association speaking.
It also points out that another way in which government policies have hit this industry is the unexpected end of postal subsidies and the imposition of the goods and services tax on magazine publishers. These actions together increased the publishers' mailing costs by 40 per cent.
Magazine revenue dropped in 1991, and of course the result of that is staff reductions.
There was a study by Price Waterhouse & Company in 1991 that showed that Canadian book publishers have dropped an average of 6 per cent each year since the free trade agreement and that four publishers have gone bankrupt.
There was also a study by Employment and Immigration Canada that suggests that the economic picture of this sector would be further eroded under the proposed North American free trade agreement. It says that Canadian printing plants are expected to lose further market share to American competition, and says that investment may even be diverted to Mexico.
The industry which has lost the most has been the fashion, or garment, industry. It is called both. It dropped from 1989 to 1991 by 45.8 per cent. It lost almost half its employees in the city of Toronto. In metropolitan Toronto it lost 27 per cent. That is a very serious drop.
Many of these workers who live in Spadina are recent immigrants with origins in China, Portugal, or the West Indies who have not been able to find other work. When

June 5, 1992
Supply
their place of employment closes they go to other places and they are not open, not hiring, or they are closing.
When I talked with some of the industrialists last year they blamed it on the goods and services tax, the high dollar that was hindering Canadian producers from getting the benefit of the tariff reductions, and on the high interest rate and the unwillingness of banks to lend to their industry at all.
One of them has moved his operation from Toronto, Ontario to Buffalo because he is getting a subsidy of $10,000 per job, as well as other subsidies from the state of New York, to move there to produce his jackets and sell them in Canada and in the United States.
Another one has taken to sourcing many of his dresses that he manufactures in Mexico or in Taiwan through the United States. He has cut his work force from about 100 to about 35, just to take account of small shifts in the demand.
These are people who need retraining, and as far as I can find out from them, the unions and the employers concerned, almost none of them have been able to get effective retraining.
The Canadian Apparel Manufacturing Association called 1991 one of the worst years on record for the Canadian apparel industry. This is its generalization. It applies much more widely than to just Toronto. According to the Apparel Manufacturers and Marketing Association of Ontario, the Consumer and Corporate Affairs figures show that the goods and services tax is having a disproportionately large impact on clothing prices in Canada.
The figures show that the GST added 1.1 per cent to the over all consumer price index. However, for clothing, footwear, and accessories the GST boosted the price by 4 per cent for men's clothing, 5.5 per cent for women, 5.1 per cent for girls, and 6 per cent for boys. It has hit this industry quite hard.
This is not directly a result of the free trade agreement, but it is related to the associated policies of this government.
It also points out that in 1991 the value of imports from the United States grew by 18 per cent while retail sales of Canadian-made apparel shrank by 13.4 per cent. This
relates to the introduction of American-owned chain stores and supplies from American sources, or from overseas sources through the United States, in good part.
Part of the effect of the destruction of almost half of the jobs in Toronto in the garment industry, which we have had for over a century is a great increase of home work. People, nearly all of them women, are pressured by poverty to take work home rather than working in a factory, which they would prefer. The wages are often around $2 an hour for piece work. This is even with their children sometimes helping and even with providing their own sewing machine, light and power and so on. What they can earn often does not go much above $2 an hour. This is vastly below anybody's concept of a minimum wage.
There are an estimated 2,000 of these home workers in the city of Toronto and they are definitely among the extreme working poor.
What we need is a basic re-examination of what has been done to the Canadian economy by the free trade agreement, by the goods and services tax and by the high interest rates. These rates have now come down, but during the two years following the free trade agreement, they added to the problems. There is also the high Canadian dollar which lost markets in the United States that might have been gained by the tariff reduction.
We believe the government should reconsider this and seriously consider giving notice to cancel the free trade agreement. It should break off negotiations for the North American free trade agreement and introduce policies that would help to revive the Canadian manufacturing industiy under independent Canadian ownership.

Mr. Speaker,
I was wondering if the member had taken a look at the March trade figures where we had the largest trade surplus ever in our history. It was $12.8 billion. Of that $12.8 billion, $9.8 billion went to the United States- those terrible Americans-with the free trade agreement. Again, this was a record export to the United States. Where does he get the idea that the trade agreement is somehow destroying us?

He mentions the fact that the duties are less for goods and garments going to the United States. They are less. He mentions the fact that there are competitive problems. That is true. However, manufacturing in Canada increased in productivity by 1 per cent last year and 4 per cent so far this year. The Wood Gundy report says it will increase by at least 8 per cent this year and 12 per cent next year. We only increased the number of manufacturing jobs in the months of April and May by 40,000. This is the largest increase of any element in unemployment. Manufacturing is all of a sudden disappearing, but jobs are increasing.
I am wondering whether the member for Trinity-Spa-dina has been there too long and has not been out looking at what is really happening in the world and Canada. We are in a restructuring. We are in a global recession, yes, but we are in an industrial restructuring where we have improved the efficiency of the economy with the goods and services tax. We have improved the efficiency of the economy with our free trade agreement and with our trade agreements generally. We have improved efficiency and business confidence. The Conference Board of Canada suggests that business confidence is up 16.1 per cent.
Where has he been? There may be problems, but part of those problems are NDP problems in the province of Ontario where legislation introduced yesterday would make it the roughest, toughest labour legislation in all of North America.
The world.

The world. Here is the member for Trinity-Spadina, a member of the New Democratic Party, who ought to turn his heat on Queen's Park. He should make sure that Queen's Park withdraws that stupid legislation and lets Canada build, grow and trade again.

Mr. Speaker, there have been quite a few statements and very few questions, but I can take some of the statements as implied questions.
As for the last one about the Labour Relations Act, it is not true that it is harsher than in other jurisdictions. In fact, in many ways, it is less harsh, even as proposed, than certain parts of legislation in other parts of Canada such as Quebec and, in general, in the countries of Europe which are doing better economically, or at least as well as North America. They have a much stronger labour
Supply
movement and they have a much stronger recognition of the obligations of employers to their workers.
It has been recognized, even by Bill L'Heureux who is the president of Hees Inc. that there has to be a balance of co-operation. He has commended the Premier of Ontario and his government for their conduct toward industry. He is not a nobody. He represents a great deal of investment. The way he spoke publicly on this matter indicates that he sees good prospects of co-operation between Ontario investors and the Ontario government in the creation of jobs.
The hon. member may want to disagree with Mr. LHeureux. He is free to get in touch with Mr. LHeureux and give him his views. Perhaps he will learn something from Mr. LHeureux.
On the matter of the recent trade surge, it remains to be seen how that translates into the employment and well-being of people in Canada. Unemployment in Ontario increased by 17,000 in the month of May. It has often happened that the over-all wealth of a country, in the usual way of measuring it, increases, but it does not get distributed where it is needed which is to the majority of the people. If the majority of the people do not have the means to feed their children well, if they have to go to food banks-as many have to in Ibronto-and if they do not have the means to get their children educated, then the economy will suffer. I think these are things that are being overlooked by the government of this country.

Mr. Speaker, I was listening with interest to the speech and the comments by the hon. member for Mississauga. I have a small comment to make.
I have a friend who is a big developer in Mississauga. I had occasion to talk to him.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I would hope the hon. member would direct his questions to the hon. member for Trinity-Spadina as he was the one who was speaking.

I had a discussion with this friend and he told me that even though he was strong financially and he built 180 houses, he could not sell 20 because there is a depression in Toronto. Here is a person who has been involved in development for a long time and he feels that Canada is moving toward a depression.

June 5, 1992
Supply
Would you like to comment about it?

Mr. Speaker, it is a very general question, but I am not sure I would say we are moving toward a depression.
A couple of weeks ago I heard somebody suggest on the radio that Canada had slipped back into the recession. I was startled because I never noticed that we left the recession. It must have happened at three o'clock in the morning when I was asleep.
I would say that we are in a depression. I hear these rosy predictions by the members opposite and the Minister of Finance, but they are being proven false by experience. I think we are in something like the 1930s again. It is something we have not had for 50 years.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to speak today about the economic crisis facing Ontario and facing my riding of Haldimand-Norfolk. Unfortunately we have an NDP government that has been running this province. As some hon. members across the way said, it has brought in some drastic legislation which I think is ill-timed and will ill-equip Ontario to compete globally and internationally in the years to come.
Ontario is at an economic crossroads. As a province and a country we face many challenges ahead. We all know that our economy is undergoing extensive restructuring as world economies become increasingly integrated. We see the effects around us every day and the reality is that we cannot compete.
As the same time, we are told by this government that we must become more competitive. However, this is without any real suggestions as to how we can go about doing this. Traditionally, we have placed heavy emphasis on our natural resources. In fact, our resource industries have been the cornerstone of our economy. We remain the leader of all industrialized countries in exporting unprocessed natural resources.
However, in recent years there has been a downturn in resource-based industries and Canada faces increasing competition from less-developed countries. We have yet, as a country or a province, to seriously deal with this situation.
The manufacturing sector, which is also an integral part of Ontario's economy, is in decline as well. This has led many people to argue that Canada, specifically Ontario, is in the process of deindustrializing. Hundreds
of thousands of manufacturing jobs, mostly in Ontario, have been lost since 1988 as a result of companies closing down or moving south of the border.
Most Canadians, I would suggest, blame free trade. Most would also blame the economic policies of this government for the downturn in our economy. Although I cannot disagree with them, I would also suggest that it is not only the fiscal and economic policies of the government, but it has been a lack of leadership, not only at the federal level but at the provincial levels, that prevents provinces across this country from really addressing the serious problem of not having enough well-trained people able to compete in this ever-changing global climate.
Whatever the case, there was a promise made by this government during the free trade agreement debate when it said it would bring in adjustment programs. It would bring in the best adjustment programs in the world. We have yet to see this happen. There are increasingly long line-ups of people who want and desperately need training. It is in my area and I am sure it is the same in the areas of all hon. members.
The people of this country, in my province and riding I would suggest, are far ahead of members in this House in knowing specifically that they are going to need training and better and more skills in order to compete. What they need from us is the dedication and the drive from members of Parliament within this Chamber in order to provide the programs whereby they can be trained.
Like many of my colleagues on both sides of the House, I understand the importance of becoming more competitive. I know that our economy is changing and that Canadian industry as a result has to adapt. I realize that we cannot turn back the clock, but we must move forward. The protectionist mindset of many Canadians, indeed of people on all sides of this House, must change. I understand these things are a fact. I understand that the government does have to play a role in restructuring our economy and I would suggest that it has been lacking in that role.
We have been told by the government that we need to become a more diversified economy and that we must become more competitive in the areas of manufacturing, science and technology, research and development and education. The studies are many as to how we can do this. There has just been a lack of any commitment by governments over the last few years on directions in
June 5, 1992

which we can take these studies and put them into action.
I am not talking about writing a blank cheque to welfare recipients. I am talking about investing in our future, investing in Canadians and investing in our country.
We need to invest in machinery, equipment and new technologies. We need to invest in infrastructure. We just cannot sit back and expect to survive. We need to control this globalization that seems to be affecting all parts of the world. As a country we need to take hold of that and make sure globalization does not control us but that in fact we control globalization.
I would suggest to hon. members sitting across that individual Canadians cannot do that themselves. It is going to take a role of government in helping individual Canadians to grab control of this globalization and to work it on behalf of Canada. We need to get Canada and we need to get Canadians working again.
Unemployment is too high. I do not care what figures are thrown out. I know Statistics Canada threw out some in the last few days. They are just simply too high. We have to address that problem first and foremost.
I would suggest that my leader has developed and put forward reasonable ways in which we can help deal with that problem. Let us get these people working first. Let us get them paying taxes, and then let us get them into the proper skills training they need.
Along with the resource based industries and manufacturing, Ontario also has an agricultural industry which is facing crisis. It really threatens the whole infrastructure of Ontario's small rural communities. Our agricultural industry remains one of the most important resource based industries we have.
As I have said before and I will continue to say-I know other hon. members on both sides of the House have said it too-in order for a country to be secure and to be proud, as you have said many times, Mr. Speaker, we must make sure our agricultural industry is the cornerstone of our economy.
Supply
I believe the sovereignty of our country is inextricably linked to us sustaining a food industry within Canada. I hate to say this-and I know you are well aware, Mr. Speaker, because in your area it is the same-small town Ontario is closing down. A lot of these places are closing down as a direct result of the decline in our agricultural industries.
Our farmers are the most productive farmers in the world, and nobody can argue that. Farmers provide Canadian consumers with the highest quality of food in the world. We have higher qualities of food than anywhere else and they do it at reasonable prices too.
I suggest to those Canadians who go across the border thinking they are getting a great deal on food that they are not. In fact they are bringing back food that is not as high quality or as high standards as we have in Canada.
No other country in the world can make this claim. The future of the family farm or a rural life is not threatened because Canadian farmers are inefficient or because of competitiveness and globalization. Instead agriculture is in jeopardy because of international trading problems, international trading agreements. Although they are very important to Canada and to certain sectors of agriculture, they have no business interfering in our internal market programs.
The government must become more sensitive to the difficulties facing our farmers instead of constantly blaming other countries for our problems. We must beat them at their own game and we must be able to compete with them internationally. We must invest in our farmers.
As a result of the situation facing our farming communities and as a result of globalization, my community of Haldimand-Norfolk is at an economic crossroads. We are really facing an economic crisis in this country which I believe threatens our prosperity for both today and tomorrow.
As a province and as a country we can move ahead, but I would suggest very seriously that the government has to take some responsibility and to invest in Canadians.
I know they will say over there that they are spending billions of dollars, but I believe we have to be more focused in where we spend that money. I would suggest the first place to start is by putting our unemployed

Supply
people back to work in some sort of program and to help with training and retraining them.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his speech. It was a positive speech. It was well focused. It hit exactly on the problems and some of the solutions that have to take place. In all fairness I think he would admit, if he had stopped to think about it, that the budget of the Minister of Finance that came down in February emphasized helping businesses streamline and modernize.
He talked about new equipment and streamlining. One of the interesting or encouraging things about the increase in imports into Canada that we have seen-and we have seen an increase in exports as well and we still have a trade surplus there-is that the increase has been in new and modern equipment coming into Canada to streamline. We are seeing it everywhere.
I will be talking in my remarks this afternoon about the riding of my friend. One of the companies I had the pleasure of touring with him in his riding, in Stratford, was the FAG Bearing Company. It is not only bringing in modem equipment. It is designing it and building it for its own use. It is very exciting and it is happening here in Canada.
I agree with him. We increased the capital cost allowance in the budget to allow companies to write off that equipment quicker. We cut their taxes to encourage them to establish now, to create jobs and to streamline.
In all fairness, the government is doing that and I think that is fine.
I heard the member say that we should get people jobs first and then train them. That is a problem, because the jobs that are available need specially trained persons to fill them. It is kind of what comes first, the chicken or the egg? I listened to him and I heard what he was saying. I do not disagree. I would much rather have people working now, but the jobs that are available require the special training and therefore we have to concentrate on training.
I am, very pleased the hon. member would commend the Minister of Employment and Immigration for adjusting and coming up with another $150 million for training because of the high unemployment in the country today and the need for that retraining.

Mr. Speaker, I agree with a number of the directions in which the minister went in that budget. Unfortunately what I do not agree with in what he did was where he was getting the money.
I understand his problems with the debt and I understand the importance of bringing the debt down, but unfortunately he took money from one important area and put into another important area without really reinvesting new moneys in these areas. I believe very strongly that we need to invest new moneys. We could get these new moneys by investing in Canadians, putting them back to work and thereby, once they are back to work, collecting taxes.
I would start that by following the suggestion of our leader for an infrastructure program. We need to invest the billions of dollars it will take, quite frankly, because we will get a double investment back from the provinces. Who is going to win? It will not be the provinces. The federal government will win on this because we are the ones who are going to get back all the taxes. It would not take a lot of money out of our operating budgets now to do that.
Another area on which I disagree with the government is the whole sense of co-operation between Ottawa and especially my province of Ontario. I see this government going in one direction and saying that we have to cut the debt and we want to put emphasis on this area and the provincial government going in a completely different direction. It does not work for Canadians.
We have to put our political differences aside and co-operate both federally and provincially in sending a strong signal to Canadians that we will help them in these areas and in training.

Mr. Speaker, today I would like to add my words in my support of the motion presently before this House.
I have been asked by my colleagues to represent the interests of northern Ontario in this debate. I thank them very much for giving me the opportunity to do so.
June 5, 1992

The economy of northern Ontario is a microcosm of the economy of Canada. We in the north depend economically on our resource based industries: mining, softwood lumber, newsprint, container board and fine paper. We manufacture in the north among other products the finest commuter rail cars in the world.
Interwoven throughout this entire process is a need for a well maintained transportation facility, especially a viable seaport. We have the largest grain storage and cleaning facilities in the world and the most qualified work force in Canada. We are capable, if called upon, to handle over 20 million tonnes of wheat a year.
In my judgment I feel it is an honour that we in the north are referred to as the hewers of wood, the drawers of water and the miners of metal. We take great pride in those things we produce from our forestry and our mining based sectors when we look at how much they add to the total economy of not only the province of Ontario but also the Government of Canada.
The economic history I have just outlined is what I consider to be the wealth of Canada. The resource based industries in Ontario and in all of Canada when we include the energy from the west are what has propelled Canada to its present economic status and are the envy of every country in the world.
Let me caution that although we talk about northern Ontario because of our resource based industries are located there does not mean that the rest of this great province of ours, nor the rest of this great country of ours, does not benefit from what we do directly in northern Ontario.
Over 17,000 jobs in the city of Toronto are created as a result of the forest industry alone. Many thousands of jobs in the city of Toronto are created as a direct result of the mining industry.
Thousands and thousands of jobs are created throughout southwestern Ontario because of the container board we produce, container board that is used in the manufacturing process from everything from the cartoning of beer, to furniture, to the harvesting of tomatoes.
Eventually these resource based wages find their way into every grocery store, every clothing store, every drug store, every automobile dealership, and particularly into areas of our province where automobiles are manufac-
Supply
tured. I am thinking of Brampton, Windsor, St. Catharines and Oakville.
With the wealth we have in this country where have we gone wrong? Where have we gone astray? Why do we have over 11 per cent unemployment in this wonderful prosperous country of ours? Why do we lack the spirit of enterprise that I sense we once had in our country?
I get the feeling that there is a sense of fear within our country. I suspect there are three fundamental reasons we are experiencing this feeling of fear or apprehension in Canada today. Fundamentally it is the direction we are trying to go from the federal perspective, from the provincial perspective, and indeed because of banking policies.
The federal government has attempted in the years it has been in office to try to change the base of the Canadian economy. It abandoned resource based industries in Canada, the very foundation of our economic strengths. It tried, with all good intentions, to convert our economy which is based on our resources to more sophisticated endeavours.
As a result we look, for example, at the job training program. What we are trying to do now is take the employees who have lost their jobs, both men and women, and retrain them to change the skills they have been able to develop over the years.
I think I have full agreement from all sides of the House that we have a work force in this country second to none when it comes to its skills that have been developed in mining, forestry, the growing of grain and in transportation routes.
We on this side of the House, and I am sure they do too, feel that we should be improving those skills so that we can be more competitive. In that way, we can keep our edge in the economic climate internationally rather than changing and trying to develop new skills.
In Ontario, which is the subject matter of what we have today, we have a provincial government that was not prepared to govern. It now faces the hard realities, as our friends have, of governing and can never in its wildest dreams deliver on the many promises that it made prior to that election in Ontario.
What it has done is what many governments do. We see what these people are doing on that side of the

Supply
House. They are raising the expectations of the people of this country and of this province beyond what anybody can reasonably deliver.
Let me mention something else with respect to Ontario, that is the changes in the Labour Relations Act that were introduced just yesterday. Everyone seems to think that there is resentment toward these changes in the Labour Relations Act, and that resentment comes from the business community.
On the contrary. I take the position that those changes that are proposed in the Labour Relations Act affect very directly every working man and every working woman in the province of Ontario. What the government is doing through these changes is upsetting the very delicate balance that we have earned over the years in the very fragile institution of employer-employee relations.
In our labour and our management negotiations, it is attempting to upset this balance. By this very legislation, it has placed itself at every bargaining table in Ontario, a place absolutely no government should venture into. It cannot be the arbitrator of a decision-making process and also be a negotiator at the same time.
You will find that this legislation is non-operable. I am prepared to say at this time that it is ill timed. It is ill conceived. It will do more damage to the working men and the working women of this province than any other legislation that has been passed by every previous government. It upsets the very delicate balance of our labour relations enterprise which has been up to this time working the best it can.
Unfortunately, the banking policies in this country do nothing to help the revival of our economy. From where we sit in this House, Canadian banks have committed themselves to ventures on a transnational stage or in assisting non-Canadian companies in buying out Canadian enterprises, rather than emphasizing the need in every small community in this country where we have small banks to providing the wherewithal, the necessary capital to assist small business and small entrepreneurs to provide that necessary capital that they need.
There is no question that employment will only increase in Ontario from the initiative and from the efforts that small business people throughout this country place into that sector of our economy. Our Canadian banks just seem not to be interested in a policy of providing this service to the small entrepreneurs in this country.
There should be no mistake about the banking services in Canada. There is no mistake that it is simply a store. People go to get a service at a bank like they do at a drugstore. They rent money from the bank and they pay something back in the way of interest. There is nothing secretive about that business.
What is important is that if they are committed to providing a service for the small business entrepreneurs in this country, they should continue to do so rather than committing all of their resources to international corporations which really do not provide any jobs in this sector of our economy.
The policies to which I refer are just the initial. My time does not allow me to go into any greater depth. Let me say that what we plan to do on this side of the House will not affect our deficit and will not affect our debt inasmuch as that is a threshold in anything that we provide or propose. It must always be considered.
Our plan, the plan that I have emphasized here today, only requires the imagination of the people in this House. It requires the imagination of our citizens. It requires initiative that we all have. It requires that Canadians face the future with confidence. We cannot face a future in this country in fear. If we make those fundamental changes, our future, especially the future that we derive from northern Ontario and the rest of the resource-based industry in this country, will make us prosperous once more and make us understand that Canada is a country that anyone and everyone in the world wants to be.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will be brief. I want to thank the hon. member for his speech. I think it was a very good speech and touched all the buttons.
In listening to him, my feeling is that he wants to be positive about things. He wants to talk positively about the country, positively about the situation and I could not agree with him more.
In my remarks to him a little later on I am going to touch on that. I am wondering if we do ourselves a disservice in this House of Commons when our entire Question Period is made up of the negatives, of the hammering away and trying to do one up on each other as to solutions, et cetera. I am wondering if that does not present to the Canadian public a very negative scenario which offers the media of course the opportunity to put the negative clips on television. When we see this type of thing, it does nothing but discourage Canadians about
June 5, 1992

spending money or going out and searching for employment or whatever it may be.
I am wondering if there is not some way that we co-operatively could present a better picture to the Canadian people, not diminishing the problems we have. We do have problems. We have got serious problems, but I think we are all working on those. I think we have to present a far more positive picture to Canadians, by us, by Canadians.
We take a look at the United Nations saying we are the best country in the world in which to live, yet when we listen to what goes on here sometimes, we wonder if that is in fact the truth.

Mr. Speaker, I thank my colleague very much for those remarks. I say that sincerely.
I am, as he is, troubled by the impression that the Canadian people may perceive as happening on the floor of the House because of the non-ability of some of us, perhaps being too partisan at times when the economy and the future of the country are at stake.
I will give the minister a small example of the parliamentary process that I think truly worked in the last two and a half weeks. It was with the Minister of Employment and Immigration. We were suffering some fairly severe consequences in Thunder Bay because of lay-offs and lack of retraining funds. I want to compliment the Minister of Employment and Immigration for the great assistance that he gave me in going through this process up to the announcement last night that $150 million was being allocated to the retraining and section 24 benefits in Canada, of which Thunder Bay will be a participant in honouring those commitments that had been made.
I do think the parliamentary process can always be improved if we approach the problems that are common to all Canadians, if we approach them with the assistance, the help and the desire to really make a difference.

Mr. Speaker, I have a quick question. I was wondering if the member felt that the changes in the financial administration type arrangements in Canada with the Bank Act, the Insurance Act and the Trust Companies Act allowing those

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate what was just said. I cannot comment on banking in other centres. I can only comment on what I see happening in the community of Thunder Bay-Nipigon that I represent. I notice there is a tendency for small entrepreneurs, tree farmers who employ 20 people, who come in visit and ask me questions. When we have industrious young people in this country who want to get ahead and dedicate themselves to doing this type of thing, employing people and not being given the opportunity to do so, says to me that there is something lacking in our banking system in this country when we will not take a chance on people rather than looking at just a balance sheet.

Mr. Speaker, just a short question.

It seems to me in the north, not only northern Ontario but all across Canada, there is

great potential to put people back to work and learn a skill that is not only short-term but long-term.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am really pleased to respond to the motion before us today that was put forward by the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River.
First of all I should start by pointing out some facts that are obvious to us sitting here in the Chamber today and debating this. I want to point out some facts about Ontario that not all people might realize. The population of Ontario is really approaching two-fifths of Canada's population. I guess 40 per cent of Canadians live in the province of Ontario.
In the way that we measure prosperity, Ontario has long been a have province. Ontario is considered not eligible to receive equalization payments because of its average per capita. It is based upon a formula that was agreed upon in 1977 for equalization payments. It is a measure that set out 32 ways a province can raise revenues or sources of raising revenues. When this was taken into consideration, Ontario, B.C. and Alberta were considered have provinces.
Most of the industry and most of the business centre of Canada is probably situated in Ontario. Ontario has long been "an engine of growth". We should not get into debate about that because when Ontario is successful, when Ontario is working and when Ontario is generating revenues and doing very well, it sure helps the rest of Canada. We have to see it in the context as a proportion.
At the same time, while I know the province is suffering, I also want to say that the problems that it is facing are also evident in other areas of Canada. Indeed, from coast to coast, we do have provinces and communities with similar situations of high unemployment.
One thing I have to say is that this particular issue we are discussing today is felt right across the country. It is more prevalent in Ontario because there are more people there.
Second, we Canadians have to pay our way. We really are not exempt from any world trends, I think the House realizes that. Some people see the economic conditions that have developed here as being in isolation to anything else around the world. We tend to stick our head in the sand. We feel that we are an isolated island, and that does not really help the situation.
What we must do in Canada is compete and thrive and go out there with the rest of the world. It is very important that we all look not just south of the border but at France, England, Europe, Germany, and Japan, right around the world, and see that a lot of people around the world are suffering from unemployment and a whole change in trade, because of globalization.
I would just like to make a remark on globalization. One of my colleagues across the way made a statement that we in Canada must control globalization. We do not control globalization at all. We are part of it. We work with GATT. We have the free trade agreement with our colleagues in the United States, who happen to be our biggest trading partners. We should be pleased that we have a free trade agreement so that we can work with them, and not be at loggerheads, to resolve difficult situations. We work with the 120 countries in GATT and all our trading partners to resolve difficult situations. We are not in isolation. We have to work in the broader world community.
Ontario is the business and industrial centre of our country. Some people think its happy state, its improved economy and growth during the 1980s should continue on and on. I really wish it would, and I am sure we all do. However, there comes a time when we do have peaks and valleys or ups and downs within the business sectors and the economy of the whole country. We have to stop and we have to restructure. That means governments must rethink positions. That means governments of the
June 5, 1992

provinces as well as businesses and educational institutions.
The need to modernize or upgrade the infrastructure may apply to some sectors more than others. I think that is why Ontario at this time may need or may be asking for help and we may have to concentrate more of our efforts on upgrading this particular area. However, it must happen across all regions. We saw this in the 1980s with the recession, and we are seeing it again in the early 1990s. We must keep up with international competition.
Let us not be surprised in any way, shape or form that Ontario appears to be hurting more than any other province. I argue that is relative to the context of Canada as a whole. In the province I come from, Alberta, over the last three or four years we have lost thousands and thousands of jobs in the oil and gas industry. The whole of the petroleum industry is restructuring around the world. We have obviously moved away from that National Energy Program that the Liberals brought in. We have deregulated and we have gone to market prices. A lot depends on the world.
When oil and gas companies lay off thousands of employees the rigs do not work. As a matter of fact, in talking to CAODC, the Canadian Association for Oil Well Drilling Contractors, about 10 per cent of the drilling rigs are working. If the drilling rigs do not work the service companies do not work. That means the men and women who provide the infrastructure and the services to the rigs, such as the mud people-we utilize mud to keep pressure under control in the hole-and those who do fracking and testing are put out of work, as are the water-haulers, the welders, the corner store people, the man or woman who runs the motel. It causes a ripple effect right across the country. All areas of Canada have problems.
Let us return to the Macdonald commission of the mid-1980s. It foresaw a lot of this period of adaptation and adjustment that is needed. It was the royal commission that said we should set about making the changes needed in anticipation of increasing competitive pressures at the international level.
Part of that anticipation was the free trade deal and the current negotiations with the United States and Mexico. They are following along the same logic.
Supply
Such adjustments are not easy and they do not come without pain, but we need to adapt. We cannot choose any other route. To use a colloquial or trite phrase, the world does not owe us a living. We have to make our own way, and most Canadians indeed know that we have to earn our own way.
They want governments to create a fiscal environment in which there are fewer regulations and fewer bureaucratic nightmares and let the private industry get on with its job. Private industry is the area in this country that promotes the jobs and develops the wealth. Governments do not develop wealth. I have to agree with a lot of the comments made by the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood.
Let us turn now from the economic realities to matters that are more social and domestic in nature. It is sometimes very tempting for all of us here in the House to concentrate on economic issues at the expense of social issues. In fact, our government does have a really substantial record of achievement on the social side.
I was watching the news last night about the tragic developments reported in Martensville, Saskatchewan, which none of us accept. It was totally devastating to hear that. It was the present minister of energy, when he was Minister of National Health and Welfare, who appointed Mr. Rix Rogers to advise him on the problem of child sexual abuse.
I do not think there is one person in this House who did not see what I saw on television last night. It is totally unacceptable. Mr. Rogers presented a report some years ago called Reaching for Solutions. Not one person can do this alone. It is only by working together that we can resolve these issues.
Mr. Rogers' report was instrumental in leading to the 1991 renewal of the family violence initiative with its special focus on child abuse. In fact, the whole area of family abuse-abuse of women, abuse of children, and abuse of seniors-has become an area of major concern for us.
The Minister Responsible for the Status of Women appointed a special blue ribbon task force some months ago specifically to look into the area of violence against women, but also taking into consideration all violence. I look forward to that report which will be presented later this year.

June 5, 1992
Supply
I also want to draw members' attention to the 1987 drug strategy program. It had a similar impact. In 1987 we put forward a specific partnership with the provinces and the territorial governments, as well as non-government agencies, to review and come to grips with the fact that drug, alcohol and substance abuse is really at an epidemic level in this country. It concerns all of us in terms of the social problems.
To deal with substance abuse in these areas we need long-term commitments. It takes time to develop relevant and appropriate programs, not only for the urban areas but for rural areas. Our aboriginal peoples are in great need of help too.
Ontario is a full partner in that. There was success. If any members would care to read the proceedings from the standing committee on health and welfare the Minister of National Health and Welfare appeared before it about five weeks ago. He presented statistics and measurements on the success rate of the drug strategy program, and it was renewed.
I believe the figure is $270 million over four years. We will be working again with our provinces and with the Minister of Justice, the Solicitor General and the minister of financial institutions to help us get to the bottom of the laundering of large sums of moneys from the sale of illegal drugs.
I also want to remark upon the needs of disabled people. This country has over three million disabled people. They are an important resource to this country.
Over the past four to six years we have worked our way toward more tax credits, more exemptions, and more ways to not only accept but also to make all Canadians realize they are a very important part. The International Year of the Disabled was a great starting point.
The federal government has assisted provincial governments and will continue to do so through deinstitutionalization and also with independent living centres. In March 1992 there was a major conference that really focused on specific areas.
Let us take a look at senior citizens and what we have done to help them. Not long ago it was recognized not only here in the House but also across Canada that we
have a very large aging population. Drastic measures are not the answer. We all have to work together and come forward with some measures that we all can live by.
We need senior independence programs and we introduced that in 1988. We are demonstrating ways we can get seniors to become and maintain their independence. The new Horizons Program that my colleague's party introduced in 1972 has proven to be extremely successful.
So all these examples I have cited are national issues with regard to social programs. They all require longterm commitments and it is something I know each and everyone of us wants to work toward.
I would also like to say we need flexibility. Obviously, if programs are extremely structured and they do not work there is very little area for manoeuvering and we have to be able to be flexible.
We are a diverse nation and with our aging population we have to look at it and come to some solutions. We cannot sit back and lament. Those challenges out there on the social side also have to be met with fiscal accountability. So while we must be fiscally accountable, and I think this is a major concern of all our constituents, we also have to be socially responsible.
The interesting area has to do with transfer payments. I will look mainly at the estimated program funding for health, education, as well as the Canada Assistance Plan.
In 1984 the federal government transferred $6.13 billion to the province of Ontario which was about $689 per capita. In 1992 we are transferring $9,924 billion and that is about $972 per capita. That is an increase of $3.7 billion or 6.2 per cent. Maybe it is not enough but working with regard to fiscal constraint is most important.
How do we get into this? I think it is most interesting. In fact, let us all come back to reality. In 1969 the government had a surplus of about $332 million. There was no deficit. There was a debt of about $18 billion. You can just watch or chart the economic development, and indeed, the spending of the government through the 1970s and early 1980s where it took us from a surplus of $332 million to a deficit of $38.5 billion. The debt went from $18 billion up to $206 billion.

Over the past eight years, we had to be fiscally responsible. We have been cutting back slowly and now this government today operates on program spending with a surplus. We have done a $29 billion turnaround and we operate with a surplus.
We have to service the debt. Out of every dollar of revenue 27 cents goes to service the debt. That is passive spending; it does no one any good.
We are paying for yesterday's programs and we are not investing in the future. Program spending is limited to 3 per cent this year. All net GST revenues and revenues from privatization are going to debt servicing and reduction. We will see by the year 1995 that the government no longer has to borrow from outside. We will not be putting pressure on financial markets and our deficit will be $5.5 billion. That is something we all have to work toward.
I just want to refer to a statement one of my constituents wrote to me. It has to do not only with his personal income tax level and what he is paying, but he also talks about the social benefits that are out there for families. He also talks about the Canada Pension Plan that he and his employer contribute to and unemployment insurance that employees and employers contribute to. His bottom line was that he cannot afford the tax that is already out there and we simply have to get it down.
I think today in discussing what the hon. member put forward, we all have to live within financial accountability. There is only one taxpayer. Canadians cannot afford any more taxes. Canadians right across this country do not want an increase in deficits. Therefore, we have to spend the money more wisely.

Mr. Speaker, I have listened with interest to the comments made by my hon. colleague, the member for Calgary Southwest, on this very important issue to Canadians.
However, the opposition motion being debated today seeks to condemn the government for its negligence toward the worst social and economic difficulties faced by residents of Ontario in modern times.
The latest unemployment figures prove this. According to Statistics Canada's figures for May, unemployment in Canada has hit 11.2 per cent. This represents an increase of 0.2 per cent over last month and is the
Supply
highest national unemployment rate since November 1984.
There are over 1.5 million Canadians looking for work. The figures announced today clearly indicate that the government's economic program and economic policies have failed. The government has certainly failed to come through on its now stale promise of creating jobs, jobs, jobs. In fact, I want to point out to my hon. colleague that her government is actually preventing many unemployed Canadians from becoming employable.
I am referring here to the lack of funds for the section 26 fee payer option. This option provides funding for UI recipients to upgrade their skills and employment marketability by attending educational institutions and taking courses.
I recently met with 400 of my constituents who were assembled by Employment Canada officials to be told that their participation in the fee payer option would be terminated.
Yet the government is currently running some nicely worded ads on national television, boasting about how competitive Canada is. The ads contain statements like: "Upgrading your skills is the key to succeeding in today's economic market". Such a statement is contemptible in view of the fact that the government has torpedoed the fee payer option under section 26. This type of propaganda is shameful.
I would like to ask the hon. member how can her government run such ads when we have 1.5 million Canadians looking for work and when there are 400 individuals in my constituency alone being told that there is no funding left in the fee payer option for them to complete their studies or upgrade their skills in order to have a better chance of finding work?
On May 12 I asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration if he would provide the necessary funding to ensure that the fee payer program would continue. The minister declined to make any such commitment.
He did, however, boast about how much money the federal government has put into training programs in Ontario this year as opposed to last year. The minister must think that we are a little naive on this side of the House. By looking at the increasing numbers of unemployed in this country, anyone would realize that there would be a greater demand for additional funds to assist the unemployed in finding work. Thus, the increase in

June 5, 1992
Supply
the funding of the fee payer option in Ontario should not be a surprise.
We have a serious unemployment problem in Ontario and throughout Canada. It is one which is even greater than last year with no relief in sight, especially given the lack of positive action taken by the government.
I would like to ask my colleague to address my question on the fee payer option. Can she tell us today what unemployed Canadians can expect to hear from her government on how they can find work?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I certainly would like to respond to the specific question on the fee payer option.
I am not too sure whether the member is aware of the Minister of Employment and Immigration's announcement yesterday with regard to the additional funding into that particular area. I would certainly be glad to provide him with a copy of what the hon. minister was putting forward.
The fee payer option which allows for training is extremely important and we do recognize, and some of your colleagues do recognize, especially the members for Thunder Bay-Nipigon and Broadview-Greenwood, that unemployment is too high and we all should be working together.

Mr. Speaker, I feel that there is a danger in this debate that those of us who are members from Ontario may be sending out a signal that we are only concerned about the problems in the economy in our own province or in our own city.
All Canadians should know that even though there is more of a primary focus on Ontario and Toronto today, and being a member from Toronto, all of us in this House really do have the same concerns for every region of this country. Traditionally in Toronto, as the member for Calgary Southwest so aptly described in the opening remarks of her speech, Ontario has been a province that has always enjoyed a very aggressive economic state of health.
For the first time, certainly in my lifetime, those of us who are from Toronto are feeling deep economic pain. I think if we can regain the confidence, that sense of "let's take a chance", that entrepreneurial spirit that is basically there-it is latent in our community, but it just needs to be reignited-then that will be of benefit not only to people who are living in Ontario, but in every region of this country.
Make no mistake about it, the people of Ontario always have shared the wealth and resources of our province with every region of this country. We do it happily and generously, and we will continue to do so but we need at this moment in time to figure out a way to get that economy going again.
This morning I had a group of students who were visiting me from my riding, Earl Grey Senior School. I had breakfast with them at the Holiday Inn on Dalhousie Street. The minister from Brampton smiles, but there is an old expression: "Out of the mouths of babes".
I've been there.

I would like to say to the minister that this was eight o'clock in the morning. It was not eight o'clock at night, and there is quite a difference.
Rather than me speak to them, I went around to each one of the students and mentioned that I was gong to have this opportunity to debate in the House today. I asked each and every one of them what were the issues that concerned them, and what were the issues that

June 5, 1992
Supply
concerned their mothers or their fathers when they sat around the breakfast table, had dinner or just chatted with them during the evening.
I must start off by saying that many of the students said that they felt things were okay. I do not want to say it was an experience where everybody was negative. There were a lot of those young people whose mothers and fathers were both gainfully employed. They felt good about things, so it was not all negative chat.
We went around to each and every person. I am not going to read off the names of everyone who was there, but I am going to put it to the table of the Elouse and to Hansard because I hope there is some way that I can give them credit for their remarks. My ideas are basically their ideas.
They were telling me things that they had heard from their parents. Interestingly enough, it seems to be the same things that most people in this House are talking about. The number one concern for the parents of these children were taxes. They really felt that with regard to the tax designs in this country, the tax systems-they did not use the words "tax design" but the word "taxes"-I know all members are hearing this-we have to meet the challenge of making our tax designs in this country more simple and more fair.
It is important to do that because if students in grade eight are beginning to hear that taxes, taxes, taxes are a negative thing, that they are a disincentive to productivity, it is going to be a part of their language, a part of their thought process. By the time they are 18, 19, 20 and get into the work force, they are going to have a negative attitude toward the system.
Before we get to a point where there will almost be a revolt in this country, we should meet the challenge of reforming our tax system.
The second thing that concerned the students of Earl Grey was the issue of job creation; finding jobs for the people in their community who were out of work. I could not help but remember a young student named Paul Stuart Vanderburg who was living with his grandmother. He was telling us that yesterday or the day before his grandmother, who looks after him, was about to lose her job. They had no other source of income except her job. The two of them lived alone in an apartment. I personally cannot imagine what that would be like, to be living
alone with my grandmother and all of a sudden she was going to lose her job and there I was in grade eight about to go into high school. That must be a real frightening experience for a young person.
Young people are concerned about the fact that somehow we get the job creation programs that do exist.
I said earlier in this House that it is incumbent upon us to put ideas forward, but there are ideas that exist in this House of Commons. The Government of Canada has to go back to some of these ideas. We do not need to re-invent the wheel. Where is this Work for Ibmorrow- Employment Opportunities for the '80s? There are 185 job opportunities there, many of them linked to entrepreneurship, giving incentives to the enterprises of this country. Rather than sending people to school to be trained, and I am not opposed to that, let the entrepreneurs of this country take people on to their payrolls and train them on the job rather than just leaving people at home on welfare or UI and becoming frustrated because they do not have anything to do, not to mention the loss of dignity. That was the second issue that concerned the students of Earl Grey Senior Public School. There is another challenge for us.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling me that my time is running out. Another issue that concerned the students was to put more support to tourism in this country. We know that it is the No. 1 job creator. The other thing they said is that government should eliminate waste and abuse of the system. Remember, these words are coming from 12 and 13 year olds. One teacher said to shift some of the defence budget to youth programs.
There was one teacher there who was an American and she said: "You know, Canadians have to be more patriotic." We need to be more patriotic. This American teacher, Mrs. Quinn, was so right when she said that we do not appreciate enough what we have in this country in terms of standard of living. Fear of job loss was another problem.
I realize I only have a short time today, but these thoughts represented here today are those of Earl Grey Public School. I support each and every one of them, but I do want to add two of my own. I think the banking institutions of this country have to re-examine the way that they handle credit with small and medium sized business. I know that the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism admitted yesterday in this House that the financial institutions need to be checked on that issue. I salute him for admitting that.
June 5, 1992

I appreciate you giving me that extra minute, Mr. Speaker, but I wish I had half the afternoon.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to the hon. member's speech and especially the portion on taxes. I know he has done a fair bit of work in regard to simplifying the taxation system. I think that is something we all want to see. In reading his book, it seemed that as he got into the system he found that he had to make exemptions that were similar to the ones that already exist in the tax system to take into account various matters that we need to do in terms of our social structure. I also noticed that a lot of the calculations take place off the particular paper itself. As I said, I welcome the attempt to simplify the tax system.
I have a couple of questions about the tax system. I know he is interested in the environment. Should there be incentives or should we be using the tax system with regard to environmental matters? What does he feel in that particular regard? I would certainly like to know his feelings on that.
There is also the whole idea of the third party who seemed to feel that all we have to do is to put more tax on what they call the rich and all our problems will be solved and the middle class will not have to pay its share. We have to raise a certain amount of revenue and we are all going to have to pay, no matter what percentages we put on it.
The third party in Ontario has apparently defined a rich person as earning $53,000. I would like the member's comments on those particular items.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity of addressing those issues.
First, I want to deal with the issue of the single tax. I have been working on this for the past three and half years with many other tax experts who are much brighter than I will ever be on tax issues. We have made sure that there are some progressive features in this tax design. Yes, we did put in a tax credit for seniors, families with children and charities. We left the RRSP in place. Beyond that, there are no other special categories.
