On the corporate side we made sure there was a $100,000 tax credit to make sure that entrepreneurship, or small and medium sized business, has that very progressive break on the first $100,000. In other words, under the single tax, there would be no tax on the first $100,000, but after that it would be 20 per cent. There is a lot of room for simplifying the tax system.
I want to address the point specifically on the environmental issue he asked about. No, there should not be any special tax breaks for the environment. I am as much committed to the environment as any other member in this House. That is the problem with the current tax system. We have been trying to run every sector of the economy through the tax system. That has created so many rules and regulations and exceptions and exceptions to exceptions in every sector of the economy that it is no longer an intelligible system.
We, as the Government of Canada, may decide that the environment is a priority issue. I believe we all agree that it should be and it is a priority issue. In that case, any money it requires can be handled through direct funding. This would be either interest free loans, low interest loans, grants or whatever, but let us not bury these grants or incentives in the tax system. Ten years from now we will be back where we are today with a system that is unintelligible.
What was your last point? I am sorry.
Taxing the wealthy.

Oh, taxing the wealthy. I used to believe that those in the NDP were into causes, but I learned my lesson this week. This is a group that is only driven by tactics. What they did to me this week I will remember for a long, long time.

Mr. Speaker, just give me one second on this. Under the current system there are many people who pay no taxes and obviously that is wrong. However, the harder you work the more you want to punish people. That is

The problem with all of us is that we were negative. That statement is a little less than accurate. Of course,

I want to say something about my own region of eastern Ontario. Unemployment has gone up to the tune of three-tenths of 1 per cent. That includes the city of Ottawa. If you remove the city of Ottawa for statistical purposes from rural Ontario, imagine how much unemployment has gone up in rural areas.
The number of unemployed has increased from 48,000 in eastern Ontario to 50,000. It is certainly quite appropriate and it is our duty to raise these things in the House of Commons today.
That is why the member for Scarborough-Rouge River should be congratulated, not just by Liberals, but by all members of this House for bringing this issue to public attention because it has to be brought to public attention.

There are those who, like the minister, will say that the opposition criticizes the government but fails to offer alternatives. That is hardly fair, since the Leader of the Opposition and next prime minister raised this matter and brought it to the attention of the media some time ago.
I refer you to a press release dated January 21, 1992, in which the hon. member for Beausejour, Leader of the Opposition and soon to be prime minister, suggested and even begged the government to set up five-point programs for economic recovery. In each case, the Leader of the Opposition explained how program expenditures would be covered. More specifically, the Leader of the Opposition asked, on behalf of all members on this side of the House and for the sake of all Canadians who are unemployed, that the government set up a program for renewal and upgrading of municipal infrastructures, including bridges, for instance.
If you ever used Perley Bridge in Hawkesbuiy in my riding, Mr. Speaker, you would find it in disgraceful condition for this day and age. It must be replaced.
The same goes for the sewers in some municipalities and for other services. We are not asking the government to build pyramids, as John Maynard Keynes emphasized long ago. We are asking it to participate in necessary projects that must be done, instead of paying people to stay home and do nothing on unemployment insurance, people who would ask for nothing better than to go back to work. We are asking the government to establish programs to give these Canadians in Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and elsewhere some dignity, but it seems that the government does not want to understand.
June 5, 1992



My very distinguished colleagues, the members for Stormont-Dundas and Renfrew-Nipissing-Pembroke, and I have been asking the government to establish a program to assist the economy of eastern Ontario. We have had meetings with municipal officials. Those few things do exist right now.
I was having a conversation with my colleague from Stormont-Dundas earlier today. We were talking about the economy of eastern Ontario. Do you know, Mr. Speaker, that the Stormont Dundas Glengarry Small Business Development Centre which is located in Cornwall has no investment money as we speak. That is funded by the federal government. It is a form of mini-bank. It put out advertisements funded by the federal government which told people: "Come in, we will help you start your own business".
Do you know what they are told when they get there? "We do not have any money". The bank has no money in the bank. It is a Tory bank. The bank that the government has established has no money in it. It advertises its program.
Last year it established the Self-Employment Incentive Program. It was, again, for Stormont-Dundas, for the Hawkesbury area, for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell and for Renfrew and so on. He announced the people who could apply. They were people on unemployment who could apply under this program and could get assistance.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate being given the opportunity to comment on the motion of my colleague from Scarborough-Rouge River today regarding the condemning of the government for the economic situation that we find in the province of Ontario, and indeed across Canada as my friend from Calgary South pointed out very clearly today.
It is not just Ontario that is hurting. It is the entire country. Coming from Ontario, the centre of Ontario, I am very concerned about the economic situation and
June 5, 1992

have been for a considerable amount of time. I want to put this in its proper perspective however.
We have gone through some very difficult times. We have all experienced employment problems within our ridings. There are many reasons for it. There are reasons of restructuring that is going on not only here but around the world. Of course employment is affected rather dramatically by restructuring.
We have seen our productivity in this country drop rather dramatically over the last three or four years, something that I am pleased to see has improved over the last year and will lead us out of the economic problem we have been experiencing.
There are other key reasons. We hear the free trade agreement caused unemployment. There is no question that the free trade agreement caused a rationalization of industries both here and in the United States. But that is a positive thing because that had to happen; it was coming anyway. We had to get through that period of time.
Some friends, some parliamentarians were visiting from Australia just yesterday. I spent a considerable amount of time with them in the afternoon. They are considering introducing a GST in Australia at the present time and were interested in our experience. I had some very good tips for them in those discussions.
They were talking about the economic situation in Australia today. Australia just had 22 per cent interest rates. Does that sound familiar? Its unemployment rate is now almost at 11 per cent and growing.
I was in eastern Europe and Europe recently. The same types of problems are being experienced everywhere because the rationalization is going on. The modernization or the changing global economy, has caused this country to reform, pardon the terminology, our economic bases and get on with the restructuring. That is what is going on.
My hon. friend from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell stood and talked about the unemployment statistics that came out today. One of the things he failed to mention was that there was an increase in the number of people able to work. Some 50,000 new people came on to the work force this past month.
Supply
What he also failed to mention was that 31,000 new jobs were created. Unemployment did not fall by 20,000. More people came on to the labour market. There were not enough jobs for those people, but 31,000 new jobs were created. I might say 20,000 of them were in the province of Ontario, and that is what we are talking about today.
Over the last two months we have seen the manufacturing sector increase its employment by 40,000 jobs. There are not nearly enough jobs yet to make up the rate of unemployment that we have seen in the last two years and want to get down. Unfortunately when we go through restructuring and bring in new equipment, new machinery and so on and so forth, employment does not follow immediately. It always lags in recovery. I am afraid we are still going to see that here.
I heard my friends from Stormont-Dundas and from Glengarry-Prescott-Russell suggest that we throw money at it and create employment. Let us be frank about that. There is not enough money anywhere to make work projects for 1.5 million people. It is just not there. The answer to the problem is not make work projects for one or two months so that people can qualify for unemployment insurance.
The answer is to get the economy going again and to create full-time meaningful jobs. That is what it is all about. That is what the free trade agreement was about. The free trade agreement was in fact to improve our economy and to have companies restructure and in fact improve their situation.
Let me just give a couple of examples if I might. Right in the riding or very close to the riding of the hon. member who proposed the motion today from Scarborough-Rouge River there is a company called Canadian Thermos Products. I want to read this into the record because it is extremely important. Its product is insulated containers; its market is the United States. In response to free trade the United States parent upgraded Canadian operations at a cost of $25 million, creating 120 new jobs; closed its older facility in Connecticut; and began producing the entire North American market in Scarborough.
That is what the free trade agreement is all about. That is what is happening for Canada.
My friend from Stratford who is sitting behind me and I spent a very enjoyable day in the wonderful riding of

Supply
Perth-Wellington-Waterloo in the community of Stratford. In the morning we had the privilege of participating in the opening of a $50 million addition which will create 200 new jobs.
One of the interesting things about this production was the new, wonderful equipment to produce precision bearings that are used in the auto industry, in the water pump industry and so on. It was fascinating to see the modern technology they brought in.
To be honest, the principals who were there from the parent company in Germany said to me that this plant in Stratford would soon be out-performing the home plant in Germany. That was good news to hear and it made me feel very proud as a Canadian, extremely proud as a Canadian.
It says an awful lot about the 900 and some workers in Stratford. As a matter of fact one of the workers received his 50-year pin with the same company when we were there. It was absolutely amazing and he is only 64 years of age. He joined as an apprentice at 14.
That is type of thing that is going on. We do not hear about these things from the headlines in the papers unfortunately. We always hear about the tragedies. We always hear about the closings. I cannot remember the last time I saw a plant opening announced on the front page of a paper or on any of our national telecasts in the news.
They might be on some of the local newscasts. I have to give them full marks, but when it comes to our national communications organizations we do not see them. If a plant closed, however, it is a front-page story. It is Chicken Little and the sky is falling in and so on and so forth.
There are a lot of very good things happening: 3M Canada in London with $30 million in a new tape manufacturing plant and Bertrand Faure Ltd. in Mississauga has just improved its production process, which is now allowing it to win new business with Japanese manufacturers locating in Canada. It is forecasting sales in the $60 million range and is investing in equipment. This is exactly what was talked about today in the debate. It is investing in equipment to improve productivity at its plant.
Basic International Network Ltd. in Woodbridge, involved women's fashion sportswear, is exporting about 15
per cent of its production to the United States and is thanking the free trade agreement for allowing it to expand into the United States.
These things are happening. I do not want to go on and on about it, but the point is that the restructuring is going on and the government is trying, to the best of its capabilities, to facilitate that change. The problem is that there is not enough money around to do what we would like to do.
I think that is fair to say.
The poor old taxpayer pays at the municipal level, in some areas at the regional level, at the provincial level, and then at the federal level. We politicians sometimes tend to forget that it is one taxpayer. There is not a group that pays the federal tax and a group that pays the provincial tax. There is one taxpayer.
We must do with the limited resources what we can do within the realm of possibility, without bankrupting the country, without borrowing more and more money or raising taxes more and more. We must do that.
We must be able to work with the resources that we have and work within a reasonable period of economic expansion. That is exactly what is happening.
I do not want to minimize the problem that we have at all, and if I left the House with that impression I did not intend to. The hon. member for Glengarry-Prescott- Russell got up, but he did not hear the quality of debate that was going on today and the discussion between our parties. In general, it has been pretty good.
I was not minimizing our problems at all. We have got them. We have problems. We all have them. We all experience them in our ridings all the time. We know what is going on out there and we are trying to help in the best way.
My friend from Broadview-Greenwood always has some positive thoughts. He is causing us fits in our ridings right now because he has some recording going around saying: "Call your local MP", and of course people are calling us and asking: "What's going on?" However, he is an original thinker. I do not always agree with him but I know people in his own caucus who do not agree with him, and that is all right. At least he is thinking and trying to do some positive things to get the economy going. That is what this is all about.

We appreciate that type of thinking.
There was an article in The Toronto Star. We are always knocking The Toronto Star in this place because-
Don't talk about The Toronto Star.
The publisher is veiy up front, he is a Liberal.
He's not a Liberal.

He professes to be a Liberal, and its editorial content is Liberal. That is fair ball. He has always been up front. He has never hidden that. However I have to give him credit for permitting an article in The Toronto Star on April 4 or April 5.
The article was written by Tom McCormack, who is an economist. He has his own company and a masters in economics from the University of Western Ontario. He has wide experience. He was one of the directors for the Anti-Inflation Board-
Good man.

-between 1976 and 1982. Strategic Projections is the name of his company and it specializes in demographics and economic modelling.
The headline of his article says: "Get Ready Canada for the Next Boom", and the introduction says:
This country, which already enjoys the second highest standard of living in the world, is on the threshold of an unprecedented expansion, writes economist Tom McCormack. But this golden age of prosperity could be jeopardized by Canadians' pessimistic national mood.
He goes on in this veiy well written article, backed with statistics, figures and so on, to talk about the positive things in this country. He talks about what is coming down the road. He says that the difficult times we are going through now are necessary so that when we come out the other end we come out running, that we are in great shape to meet the challenges.
That is exactly what is going on in this country today. Although it is not obvious yet we are starting to see very positive signs. Never in the history of Canada did we have record exports like we did in March, and record exports to the United States of America. There was $9.8 billion worth of goods exported to the United States in March 1992.

In the first quarter we had wonderful export figures. We export 25 per cent of what we produce. We depend on exports in this country far more than the United States. It only exports 12 per cent of what it produces, Japan's figure is 14 percent. It is so very important.
These signs of improvement in our exports are a sign that the economy is improving. If the economy in the United States starts to pick up we are going to see phenomenal progress because that is where we export most of our goods. We exported $3 billion to other countries of the world and $9.8 billion to the United States in the month of March. That is a good sign and it is starting to happen. We are very pleased about what is going on.
Everybody takes these statistics and figures and uses them. They can use them in many ways. Politicians have a great knack of doing so.
As you do.

I do it too, sure. Of course I do.
There were 31,000 new jobs created, over and above last month. That is a fact. It is right there. I am not juggling the figures.
Part-time.
I said that 57,000 or 58,000 came into the labour force this month, so there were 20,000 that did not get jobs out of that group. I am admitting that.
Let us talk about the unemployed.

We want to get the economy improving and continue to increase these exports and manufacturing jobs that will create spin-offs, such as people buying homes and all the other things that go on. That is exactly what we are doing.
I just want to give one quick example, in terms of interest rates alone so people understand what is going on out there. If we took the interest rate of a five year mortgage, in August 1981-this may not be fair-if I had a five-year mortgage it was at 21.75 per cent.
Today that same mortgage is at 9.75 per cent. The difference to a family's pocket is $7,812 per year. That is money in its pocket. That is what it means. These falling interest rates mean that the mortgage rates on a five-year mortgage come down.

On a one-year mortgage it is saving $8,652 per year. That is just in mortgages. Those are types of savings to the people who finance their mortgages.
Let us talk about a small business loan. Let us say a person got a piece of equipment for $100,000 in 1981. He was paying $1,979 per month on that loan. Today he is paying $688 per month. That is a saving of $1,291 per month or $15,492 per year.
That is what is helping the economy. The interest rates are helping the economy. There is no question that with lower interest rates we are going to encourage small business and we are going to encourage young people to buy new homes. Today I just found out that the three-year rate is at 9 per cent. I cannot remember when the mortgage rates were that low. I am pleased that they are so low.
I am convinced that because of this increased activity in manufacturing and in exports and the increased economic activity we are seeing in our country that we are going to see things improve, not only in Ontario but right across this country.

Mr. Speaker, maybe I could finish the question I started a while ago.
The member was in the House when I was reading a letter from a constituent of mine. I felt this person's letter quite clearly described the plight Canadians are in today across this country. I will not repeat what I said but he is asking for my help. He has no income whatsoever.
He says that social services told him: "Because my wife works I am not entitled to any help from the UIC", even when he offered to pay it back. His wife earns only $13,476 after taxes, Canada pension, and UI. Therefore, he is not entitled to any social benefits. He is not entitled to UIC. He is an unemployed man and is not entitled to anything.
He has been using his Visa to buy the gas for his car so he can go looking for work. He is not complaining. All he wants is the opportunity to go out and work. He is driving a 1980 car. He is in a position in which he needs to be retrained. He is not educated and needs retraining. We now know there is no money in the budget for retraining. He is asking me, as his member of Parliament, to help him out. What is there for me to offer this person? He is
only one of thousands in this country who are in this position.
I ask the member opposite, what can I tell this gentleman to do? Where can he go so that he can be offered some hope in this wonderful country of Canada?

Mr. Speaker, I do not mean to demean the individual at all. We all have examples in our ridings of people who are desperately searching for work and looking for jobs.
I will reiterate what I said. There is unfortunately not enough money in this country alone to help everybody at this particular time. That is unfortunate, but there is not.
Yesterday the minister added another $150 million for training. Hopefully the individual the member refers to will be able to get into a program, but maybe not. Maybe it will be over-subscribed, maybe it is now. Maybe he is further down the waiting list. I do not know.
The hope I can give him is that the country is coming out of a recession and employment opportunities are slowly getting better. There were 31,000 more people employed in the month of May than there were in April. It is improving, though not fast enough for our liking. We would like to see it happen much faster. However it is improving and we have to hold hope out for those people.
If we are reading letters I can read out a letter that my colleague the Minister of Finance received yesterday. It is from an individual who is unemployed and who has been out looking for work for months. He apologized for his contribution to the party. It could only be $150 because he is unemployed. Yet, he said: "You are on the right track. Keep doing what you are doing because we can see signs that the economy is getting better and I am hopeful I will be able to get a job in the not too distant future with an improved economy". He understands the problem all levels of government in Canada are having. Here is a person who is unemployed and still believes in the democratic-
Oh, oh.

Members can make fun of him. They can sit there and laugh at him. They can make fun of the individual if they want to, but it is not funny being unemployed. Here is someone who believes in the democratic process and is prepared to participate. Do not sit there and laugh at an individual who writes a

letter like that. I did not laugh at your constituent. You should not laugh at this one.

Mr. Speaker, I listened attentively to the minister's remarks. He talked about the economist Tom McCormack, and I too read the article in The Toronto Star. I subsequently had some discussions with Tom McCormack and he sent me his latest papers on projections. They were good. I actually believe that the 1990s are going to be better than the 1980s.
However, what we are talking about here today is trying to do something, and not in 1994, 1995 or 1996. Today we are trying to address the problems of the 1.5 million people in Canada who are unemployed. Specifically, we are trying to put a tighter focus on the .5 million in Ontario who are trying to get back into the work force.
The minister was part of a parliamentary task force on employment opportunities for the 1980s. I have referred to this task force at least a dozen times in this House in the last 60 to 90 days. It is a good report.
The report recommends one thing over and over again. The report talks about apprenticeship training, but it talks specifically about linking training to on-the-job experiences. In other words, use the 1.7 million enterprises in this country as partners in taking people off unemployment and putting them into a factory or an office and training them on the job.
Would it not be a much more dignified productive experience if instead of giving out welfare or UI cheques to figure out a mechanism whereby the employer would take people off UI and put them into the factory? Would it not be a much better experience to have a joint venture using those funds and that business? Besides giving people back their dignity, they also become taxpayers and we would be developing skilled workers for the small enterprise which will provide that badly needed support to go into the nineties.
The minister was a part of that task force. Why does he not figure out a way to motivate his cabinet colleagues to make that happen tomorrow?

Mr. Speaker, I am glad he asked that because I can say the minister did that a few weeks ago.

The Minister of Employment and Immigration has a project now in New Brunswick. One of the problems, both technically and philosophically, is that it is a wonderful theory until we come to the employers because there is a union in there. The union says: "Look. Last guy on, first guy off."
If that report is thoroughly read, it will be seen that although we made those types of recommendations we listed all the problems. Canada for so many years has always had the luxury of importing its skilled labour. Because of that, we never really established good apprenticeship programs because when industry needed people, boom, off to England, off to Germany, off to Italy, off to France, off to Portugal, bring them in, set them up.
Today that same luxury is not there. We are behind in our training. Canadian businesses spend one-half of 1 per cent of their income on training. The United States of America spends twice that, about 1 per cent. Japan spends 2 per cent. That is four times what our businesses spend on training and retraining.
It has to change. I agree with the hon. member. We said that in our report but there are so many problems in getting employers to do that. Right now, when you say that you want to train somebody on the job, they say that right now, they have no work for them to train them on, or they say that they need somebody who is really specialized.
I might add one of the other problems in that report that has to do specifically with the hon. member's question is that industry does not plan for the future. This is one of the things my friend from Calgary West would tell you. I am sure the chairman from Montreal would tell you the same thing.
When the industries were asked: "What kind of a person are you going to need three or four years from now," they could not tell us what they needed. They could tell us what they needed next week, but they did not know what they would need four years from now. A person cannot be trained in a week to take a job.
There has to be attitudinal changes. I say to the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood, I believe that report is as fresh today as it was back in 1981-82. I have no disagreement with that.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to rise and speak on this motion this afternoon.
The debate has been quite interesting. It certainly has highlighted some of the problems that the largest province in Canada is now facing, problems that have been created in large part by the fiscal and economic policies of this government.
I just want to go back to a few comments other people have made and then come to the things I want to say myself.
One of the interesting things a previous speaker from Calgary was talking about is that this is a world-wide recession and that many countries are having downturns in their economies. The United States is suffering, Japan is suffering and other countries are suffering. There is some truth in that.
But there are also many areas where that is not true. Canada has lost 23 per cent of its industrial and manufacturing jobs. In that same period of time, the United States has lost 6 per cent. So in the Canadian economy Canadian manufacturing is shrinking by 23 per cent. The bulk of those jobs or a great number of them would be in the industrial heartland of Ontario.
The United States has suffered 6 per cent. Now that is quite a dramatic difference. It is said that in the free trade agreement the United States has lost jobs. Yes, it probably has in the same period of time. But it has lost 6 per cent and we have lost 23 per cent.
The member for Calgary Southwest also talked about Japan's economic downturn. Well, I happen to have been there a few months ago and I hate to inform the hon. member but there is a shortage of workers in Japan. There is a shortage of skilled, unskilled, any variety of workers. Japan, for the first time in its history, has to deal with the problem of foreign or itinerant workers. There are now somewhere in excess of 300,000 people from Baluchistan, Pakistan working in Japan. Many of them are there illegally but industries are dependent upon them.
So, when this government gets up and says that it is a world-wide problem and we have nothing to do with it, it really should examine this recession and its impact.
We went into the recession earlier, we went into it deeper, and we are going to stay in it longer. That is because of the government policies of introducing the GST, which has crippled our retail industry, because of the free trade deal, which has devastated our total balance of payments, and because of our high interest rate, which is still higher than in the United States. It has kept our dollar artificially high, thus making exports much more difficult and imports cheaper. This has been kept up over all the years that the Tories have been in power.
It has created difficulties, particularly in the province of Ontario, in the industrial heartland of Canada. So while the province is having economic difficulties because of the economic conditions created by this government, what has the government done to assist the province and the people?
I want to talk about just a couple of things that the government has done. The federal government of course has cut back on the Established Programs Financing which should be there for the provinces to assist in health care and post-secondary education, that great thing the government talks about, education.
There was a formula in place. The formula was based on so much going to the provinces increased by the increase in gross national productivity. It was not by expenditures, not by anything else, but as the country got more wealthy the money was to be transferred to the provinces based on the creation of additional wealth.
What happened? It started back under the Liberals. The Liberals decided that they had the formula but they did not like it and so they started cutting back. Even before the Tories came to power the cutbacks for Ontario amounted to nearly $300 million lost in 1982-1983 and another $360 million lost in 1983-1984. Today the losses are up to $2.6 billion a year. That should have been coming to that province based on the increase in the wealth of this country. A total of $11 billion was cut from the province, not only from health care but also from post-secondary education.

This is at a time when government member after government member stands up and says: "One of the things that is going to save Canada and guarantee the future of young Canadians is for them to get an education". So the government cut back the money going to the provinces for post-secondary education. It was cut back dramatically in the case of Ontario.
Look at what has happened in Ontario as the impact of this recession hits it in terms of the number of people on unemployment insurance or relying on income assistance.
The government anticipated this recession quite nicely because three years ago, it bailed out of any responsibility for directly financing or even partially financing the unemployment insurance system. It dumped that responsibility on employees and employers. That includes small business, municipal infrastructures, hospitals, schools which had to come up with the additional money.
Even with that the government then reduced the number of weeks a person could qualify for UI, it increased the number of weeks they had to work to get UI, and even with that in Ontario the number of people collecting UI went up dramatically to over 23 per cent from November 1990 to November 1991. The number of people who exhausted their UI in November last year was 32,000 which is up 111 per cent over the previous year.
What happens to the exhaustees? They have to go on income assistance. The income assistance case-loads have gone up dramatically. The case-loads are up to a point where there are now nearly 600,000 people receiving income assistance in the province, an increase of 32 per cent from January 1991. That is the number of cases. The number of individuals involved is 1.131 million. That is 1.131 million people receiving welfare.
Of course the federal government realized that it had sloughed off its responsibility under unemployment insurance. It had dumped it down to the provinces, to welfare costs. But lo and behold, it was responsible for 50 per cent of the cost of welfare and thought: "Aha, we cannot have that. We cannot be held responsible for the unemployed. We cannot be responsible for mothers looking after children. We cannot be held responsible for the damage we have caused. We will have to limit the
Supply
amount the provinces can claim so it is no longer 50/50. We will limit the increase to 5 per cent." It knew full well that the increase in demand was around 32 per cent to 35 per cent but it would limit its liability to 5 per cent.
What does that cost the province of Ontario? The costs to the province of Ontario amount to an accumulated total of something in excess of $3.5 billion. In 1990-91 it was $400 million and in 1991-92 it is $1.3 billion. In 1992-93 it will be $1.8 billion.
The federal government said that it was not only washing its hands of the responsibility for creating this recession, it was not only washing its hands of trying to create employment and get people back to work, but it was going to systematically slough off to the provinces the financial responsibility for the people who have been so adversely affected. It sloughed off in terms of post-secondary education, health care, the number of people on income assistance and those receiving other types of support.
The government did not stop there. There are now other areas where it is sloughing off on the provinces. It has totally cancelled the co-op housing program and its responsibility to provide social housing. It is now cutting back on other social housing programs. We now have cutbacks in social housing right across this country.
It affects Ontario specifically by reducing the number of units being built by 1,957. That is nearly 2,000 units. This has an impact on people's lives. It comes at a time when CMHC has estimated that 560,000 Canadians need social housing to obtain adequate, affordable housing. With 560,000 people needing housing, what has this government done but cut back. It also cuts back on jobs because housing is one of the fastest generators of jobs in this country. It is labour-intensive construction. It employs people directly in the trades, in home building, in the supply industry supplying materials, in the manufacturing industry manufacturing materials, light fixtures, air conditioning systems, furnaces, everything.
It also has a multiplier effect very quickly because if those people are working they buy from the retail stores, they eat out in restaurants and there is a very quick acceleration of employment. Housing is probably one of the best investments a government can make to stimulate the economy.

There are other things that the federal government has done. I want to just briefly compare some of the things that the federal government has done and what the Ontario government has done in spite of the fact that the offloading has been on it.
Ontario started a job training fund in which it put in $1.1 billion over three years. It expects to create 100,000 jobs and provide training for another 800,000 people. An additional $930 million for worker retraining and adjustment is being scheduled for 1992-93. The federal government cut $100 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy Program. It has no momentum to try to deal with the high unemployment. The Ontario government immediately committed to building 20,000 new non-profit housing units. The figure in the street is 2.12 person years of labour, work, for every housing unit, plus the spin-off, which is probably three or four times that.
What did the federal government do? It cancelled the co-op program and it cut 2,000 housing units from the social housing program.
Infrastructure programs: The Ontario government immediately put in $34 billion in capital funding for schools, roads, homes for the aged, and other public facilities. This will support 67,000 jobs in 1992-93 alone.
What has the federal government done? It has ignored calls by all of the municipalities, all the mayors across this country, to fund a municipal infrastructure program on a shared cost basis with the provinces, the municipalities and the federal government.
This is municipal infrastructure that must be done. These are not luxuries. These are things that if we do not do it now they are going to cost us more in three or four or five years to do. These are basic sewers, roads, sewage treatment plants, hospitals, schools, all of the things that form the heritage that our kids need to make the community strong, to provide the economic base and the economic infrastructure for our small businesses and our industries.
This motion in one sense is very timely today. It focuses on the real difficulties being experienced by people right across Canada, and certainly by people in the province of Ontario. It shows that this government is
either lacking in the will to solve the economic problem or the knowledge of how to solve it.

I cannot help it, but when I get an opportunity to ask a question of the New Democratic Party, I cannot resist the temptation.
The member talks about many of the problems that we are having in the economy today. One of the problems that we are having is the fact that there has been almost a 50 per cent reduction in the amount of foreign investment that has come into the province of Ontario. One of the reasons why there is a hesitancy to invest in Ontario right now is because of the uncertainty created by the labour legislation that is being put forward by the NDP government.
I want to be perfectly clear to this House and to the member that we are not anti-labour here. We are not talking about that. The member is a fair member and I know that he understands that. But 85 per cent of the jobs that are created in the province of Ontario are created by small and medium-sized businesses. There is a skittishness out there in the market right now because of this labour legislation which, rather than advancing the cause of labour, seems to be frightening off entrepreneurs and investors. Does the member not think that part of the problem we are having in the province of Ontario is as a result of what appears to be an almost indifferent attitude toward small and medium-size business and some of the difficulties they are having? I am talking about a kind of indifferent attitude from the NDP Government of Ontario toward that sector of our economy?
Could the member try to explain it to this House and to the people of Canada and specifically to Ontarians? I cannot understand the proposed advantages of this labour legislation that the province is putting forward at this time.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to have that question. One of the things that I want to make sure the member understands is that the New Democratic Party is probably the greatest supporter of small business in Canada and has been over the last number of years.
We realize that the generation of jobs in this country has been by small business. If we take a look at the jobs that were created up until the point of this recession,

most of those jobs were created by companies employing less than 100 people.
One of the things that we are also aware of is that many of the difficulties that small businesses have experienced in this country is because of the legacy that they have inherited from the Liberals and the Tories, particularly the tax unfairness of the tax system created by the Liberals. They at the national level particularly created tremendous tax loopholes for the very wealthy and the big multinational corporations. Who had to pick up the slack of those big tax loopholes? The average Canadian.
Small businessmen and small businesswomen are average Canadians. I know. I ran companies prior to being elected.
We have in Ontario a legacy left by the provincial Liberal government of not only a whole backlog of economic problems in terms of unfair taxation, but also a whole backlog of things that it never got around to doing that it should have done. One of them was to update and modernize labour legislation.
Even the Liberal leader in the Ontario legislature yesterday admitted the only thing that she could think of to say that was wrong with the bill that was being proposed was the fact that it was poor timing. It was good legislation, but poor timing. The Liberals and the Conservatives had 20 years to bring it in. That was poor timing and it will always be poor timing.
The New Democrats are certainly willing to bring forward and modernize labour legislation to bring back economic stability and a fair labour climate within the province of Ontario, as they will do in Saskatchewan, as they will do in British Columbia and as they will do in Canada when they form the next government.

Mr. Speaker, now that we have established some of the weaknesses of the Government of Ontario, we perhaps could give a further analysis of what they are doing or should I say not doing on behalf of young people.
The member spoke at length about the importance of youth in Canada and indeed in the province of Ontario. I have a couple of questions. We have two examples of NDP governments, one in British Columbia and one in Ontario. On the one hand the same member that speaks

to the issue of student support and support for young people must realize by now that the latest budget by the Ontario New Democratic Party basically stated that there was going to be a $10 million cut in Ontario's student assistance plan at a time when young people are desperately looking for work.
On the other side, in British Columbia we have another premier who has cancelled a very successful environmental youth corps for young people.
The NDP must come to grips with reality. We cannot be speaking and saying on the one hand. When we analyse exactly what is done I will tell you that we are suffering on both ends of the country.
We have a federal government that is Conservative, and we have a provincial government that is NDP. I will tell you that times are tough in the province of Ontario. We would like to soon have an election to re-establish things and have some order in this country.

Mr. Speaker, I was just looking at the figures that I have here in terms of the loss of federal revenue for post-secondary education.
Health and post-secondary education amounts to $2.6 billion in Ontario this year. One-third of that is for post-secondary education. That is around $800 million. It is not surprising that if they have $800 million less coming from the federal government that they have to curtail this by $10 million.
The bulk of those cuts in transfer payments started under the Liberal administration in 1977. It did it again in 1982 when it cut back on the revenue guarantee. It did it in 1983.
In British Columbia, one-third of all of the cuts to post-secondary education and health care that are now in existence came because of the Liberal administration in the early 1980s and not because of the Tories.
It was well documented. It is there. The Liberal government in the early 1980s started the erosion of health care and post-secondary education in its cutbacks to the provinces and all that happened is that the Tories learned from the Liberals.

Mr. Speaker, I listened to my hon. colleague talk about Ontario and how short we are of money and at the same time about more government spending. He had a litany that took him 20 minutes to illustrate government spending. I would just like to give him a few statistics and ask him to respond.
About 10 years ago the budget in Ontario was $18 billion. Let us inflate that budget and go back 10 years in Ontario. We did not have a crowded health care system. We did not have an under-funded school system. We did not have an infrastructure that was collapsing. In fact things in Ontario were generally not bad relative to all those things that the member was talking about.
It spent $18 billion. Inflate that. That takes it to $28 billion in today's dollars. Add $5 billion because the population of Ontario has grown. That takes it up to $33 billion.
Would the member mind explaining to me why this year in Ontario they have to spend $52 billion to give in Ontario what 10 years ago $33 billion would have bought?

Mr. Speaker, I think we should take a look at the history of increased spending and look at it particularly when Bob Rae inherited the terrible mess that was left over by the Liberal administration about 18 months ago.
The increase in the spending in those years was dramatic. That is where the difficulty is. During the boom years when Ontario should have been budgeting and planning for the economic downturn, it should have been building up reserves and doing all of the positive things. It should have made sure that its infrastructure was in place and that there were proper roads and schools and all of those things. It blew it. It frittered it away.
The Liberals just did not know how to spend. I want to contrast that to exactly what happens in Sweden under a democratic socialist government. It built into the economy mechanisms that during the boom times when things were good companies were forced to put aside so much money that they could then, when things were down, bring out for economic expansion.
They were forced to put aside money so that when things went down, job training and job creation could be brought out. You cannot expect to deal with the crisis and the mess left by this Tory and Liberal government after 25 years in Ontario and expect Bob Rae to solve it in 18 months. Give him five years and he will solve it and he will also be re-elected to serve as an NDP premier with Audrey McLaughlin as the NDP Prime Minister.

I just want to remind him and this House and the people of Canada that under Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau, there were more small business start-ups in this country than in all the years of government put together. We should never forget the fact that it was under the Liberal Prime Minister that the Small Business Loans Act came into play. The expansion of the Federal Business Development Bank, not to mention numerous other incentives, used the power of entrepreneurship to put people back into the work force.
I remember when the member for Winnipeg South Centre was the minister of employment, he came out with that very successful NEED program. It put close to

Mr. Speaker, just before I answer that question, the Liberals and Tories seem to be enjoying this questions and comments period. I would ask for unanimous consent of the House to extend this period for another ten minutes so that I can continue.

Mr. Speaker, I
appreciate the opportunity to speak today on the subject
June 5, 1992

of the difficulties faced by the residents of Ontario. After that last exchange it is somewhat difficult to even respond.
If I may just digress for a moment, I might say that the labour legislation proposed by the NDP government of Ontario is causing some concern. As was mentioned by the member for Broadview-Greenwood, it certainly is in the area of investment in the province of Ontario.
There is one particular company in St. Catharines which is a multinational corporation which has kept it quiet, but made it clear, that there is no further investment to be made in their particular organization in Ontario at the present time. In fact, after reviewing the legislation, that may continue as well. That is the type of thing that is occurring in the province of Ontario now.
In addition, the member spoke about the tax system. It is very interesting that promises were made such that the tax system would be reformed. They had a commission on fair taxation. They were going to have a minimum tax on corporations. Lo and behold, when they looked at it they found out that maybe corporations were not going to have a minimum tax. Maybe they were paying their just due and perhaps putting an extra burden on them would affect their competitiveness.
It is surprising how the strictures of government seem to change the viewpoints and promises that are made during an election campaign. I am sure people will keep that in mind as they review these various matters.
Obviously, it has been a difficult time over the last few years. There have been difficult social and economic circumstances and, of course, this is extended to the province of Ontario as well. As my riding is in the province of Ontario, we have had some difficulties also. However, to say that it results from the negligence of the government and to lay it entirely at the feet of the government is not being completely above board.
I am sure it is.
Which government?

Let us look at some specific circumstances. My community has been hurt by the recession and by what has gone on.
Supply
The announcement a few months ago that 2,300 jobs were going to be lost because of the closing of a General Motors foundry in St. Catharines was obviously devastating to the community. The immediate knee-jerk reaction was to blame the free trade agreement. That is interesting.
The auto pact has been in effect since 1962. It has done wonders for the North American automobile industry and the automobile industry in Canada has benefited greatly. It integrated the entire North American automobile market with certain safeguards, as they are called. One of those safeguards is that we will continue to produce as many cars as we consume here in Canada. The interesting fact is that we produce almost double the amount of cars we consume in Canada at the present time. We have benefited greatly from the auto pact.
The other safeguard is that the big three automakers are able to import parts from offshore duty free if they maintain a 60 per cent Canadian content level on the cars produced here above that which existed in 1962. They have always done that and they have continued to do that.
Mr. Speaker, I know you realize that you do not mix that with the 50 per cent content rule that exists in the free trade agreement. That does not apply to the big three although the big three have always maintained much more than that 50 per cent North American content.
On the day the announcement was made about those lost jobs in St. Catharines it is interesting that approximately 15,000 jobs were lost in the United States on the same day. The simple fact is that there is an overcapacity in the automobile market. This overcapacity has come about as a result of the imports. They are making greater and greater inroads into the North American market over what the North American automobile manufacturers are producing.
Unfortunately, a lot of that was the result of people thinking the quality of North American cars was not as good as the imports for quite a period of time. The big three have made certainly a great effort in order to improve their quality and the quality has improved. They are trying to win back their market but they have not been able to win back that market share. General Motors was set up throughout North America for a certain market share. That market share has been lost. Whether

Supply
it will be regained or not is something we will have to wait and see.
Pessimists would say they are not going to regain that market and as a result the industry has to rationalize down to the capacity they need in order to meet the market demands. They have done that and as a result St. Catharines is going to be affected by that.
It would nice if people would purchase North American cars and get back to the capacity that previously existed. Then there would not be any pressure on them to close the foundry in St. Catharines. The foundry in St. Catharines cannot be expanded and as a result there are larger foundries n the United States that can take on the capacity that is necessary to meet the demands of the marketplace. The foundry in St. Catharines was modem and efficient, yet because of its mere size, this is causing the difficulties.
I also might mention that the foundry represents a portion of the entire factory in St. Catharines. It is not the closing of the entire factory. There are still approximately 6,000 jobs there, but of course they have to justify their existence just as the company in Oshawa has to justify remaining intact within the General Motors system.
The auto pact has worked well for us. It is intact. To say in a knee-jerk way that the loss of those jobs is a result of the free trade agreement is not being intellectually honest and cannot be allowed to continue in that manner.
Obviously we would like to save those jobs and see other jobs created. That is going to take an effort on the part of all of us in working together. To lump those 2,300 jobs together and say that that is a result of the free trade agreement is just not correct. These are the kinds of figures that the opponents to the free trade agreement come up with.
In the North American free trade negotiations-and this is where we may have an internal debate within Ontario-it would be nice to see the North American content be increased for the cars that are able to be exported duty free to the United States. I certainly would like to see a figure of 60 or 65 per cent come out of the North American free trade agreement. That will be beneficial to a community such as St. Catharines. There
will be an internal debate within Ontario with the import manufacturers as to whether that is going to be beneficial in their particular case. Something such as that would certainly help the North American automobile industry and I will be watching very closely for that.
That was one example of what has happened. The knee-jerk reactions of some people indicates that happened as a result of the free trade agreement when it is not a function of the free trade agreement. The auto pact is intact. There is an over-capacity in the North American market. To say that those jobs were lost, to lump them in with all the other jobs that were lost, and say it is because of the free trade agreement is not correct. In a lot of instances that is what is occurring in other areas as well.
There have been losses as a result of the free trade agreement, as the Minister of State indicated. There were losses as a result of the implementation of the auto pact as well.
It was interesting that a union leader came before the St. Catharines city council when I was there and said: "You cannot allow the free trade agreement to go ahead". We debated and asked: "What was your initial reaction to the auto pact?" He said: "We were opposed to it. We did not like it. We thought it was going to be bad for us". We asked: "What is your reaction now?" His answer was: "Under no circumstances can you allow the auto pact to be affected by the free trade agreement". It was not. I asked: "What happened to you when the auto pact came into effect?" His answer was: "I was driving cab for a while". He was driving cab for a while because the plant in St. Catharines, which had made all the components for cars produced in Canada at that particular time, switched over to simply producing engines. It had longer production runs and better quality. After that initial restructuring it resulted in more jobs being created.
More cars are produced in Canada than we consume. We have been a net beneficiary of the auto pact. Similar benefits will flow from the free trade agreement but there is going to be a period of restructuring. A recession and an over-capacity in the automobile market in North America cannot be used as excuses to say that the free trade agreement is not working. To say that is to be intellectually dishonest.
June 5, 1992

I am glad to see that the Liberals have changed their position. Now they are saying that the free trade agreement should be renegotiated. It will be interesting to see what points they say they are going to renegotiate. However, accepting the free trade agreement and accepting the globalization that has occurred it is gratifying to see they have realized that is going to be their position. That was the position enunciated by their government House leader in this House during previous debates.
Free trade has benefited the Niagara peninsula. One industry that has really benefited is the grape and wine industry. During the negotiation of the free trade agreement it was widely assumed that the grape and wine industry would be a big loser as a result of the free trade agreement. There was no protection for the grape and wine industry and it had to rationalize very quickly.
It is interesting that it has produced high quality products and this year it has seen its market share jump drastically. It used to be that all surplus grape products were purchased by the federal government. Unfortunately, the grape and wine industry went through a period where it produced what might be called "pop wines" and so on, and again it developed a reputation in terms of the quality of its products that was not the best.
As a result of the free trade agreement and the Ontario legislation preventing Lambrusca grapes from being put into the wines it has now developed quality wines that are winning awards around the world. Entrepreneurs have realized that and moved in and used the grapes produced in the Niagara peninsula to secure these awards around the world.
An example is Don Ziraldo at Inniskillin Wines. His ice wines have won many awards.
This year there was not any surplus, the industry sold its entire grape product. Ontario wines are being sold in the United States and they are being sold in England. Unfortunately interprovincial trade barriers in this country prevent Ontario wine from being sold to Quebec and other provinces. It is easier for Ontario wine to get into the United States and even England than it is to get into the provinces of this country.

The result of the free trade agreement is that the industry has become more competitive, has produced better wines, and has succeeded. The fact that it cannot even sell in various provinces makes no sense. In that regard I certainly hope the constitutional negotiations succeed and we do create a true common market among Canadian provinces.
We spoke about training earlier today, and I think we all agree that training is most important. We will see what occurs from that particular aspect. The constitutional proposals indicate that the provinces will take over all training. That is something that causes me some concern because the federal government has done a commendable job in the training area.
It was interesting that in the testimony before the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee when the individuals who head the training assistance boards came before the committee they indicated that there certainly was enough money in all the provinces and the federal government for training. It was a matter of directing it. The provincial government itself has its skills training within 10 different departments. It is in the process of bringing those under one umbrella. However, the turf wars that will go on are going to hurt the individuals who need training. That is something we have to deal with.
The motion also refers to the social situation here in Ontario. I would like to touch on that briefly. My community has been hurt very badly recently by the deaths of two young girls and by what appears to be the accidental death of a third young lady. It has created a great deal of fear and anxiety about our system of law and order and the safety of our streets. This random violence has to be something that we all condemn, especially violence against women.
I am glad to see that the federal government is putting money into such things as transition houses and other things that will fight violence against women. However, there is also a role to be played through our justice system. I am glad that the federal government has taken some steps in that regard. They include the Extradition Act amendments which prevent individuals such as Charles Ng and Joseph Kindler from getting the benefit of being in our country and having the protection of our system here.

June 5, 1992
Supply
There is much discussion about the Young Offenders Act as well. It is interesting that the penalty for murder in the Young Offenders Act has been increased. Some people do not feel that is quite enough. There are jury considerations as to why the penalty of five years less a day was taken. Of course we should continue to review the young offenders' system. Perhaps through a system of education people will see that this system is not as lax as some seem to feel at the present time.
There is no provision for parole under the Young Offenders Act. Every sentence that is handed out under the Young Offenders Act is expected to be served for that entire term. Compared to an adult sentence, in a lot of instances the young offender is serving more time than the adult offender for a similar offence.
With regard to corrections, the corrections bill has been passed. I would like to read an editorial from the St. Catharines Standard, which says:
Judges should get a little more power and police should get a little relief as a result of a long overdue bill passed last week in the Commons.
Only criminals will regret the proposed law which will make it more difficult for violent criminals to get parole from prison. Victims and their families will welcome the fact that they will be provided with more information about offenders and their movements on parole or day passes, in addition to being allowed to attend parole hearings and give their views, regardless of a prisoner's wishes.
Defence lawyers and prisoners' rights advocates have criticized the bill, claiming it is a political over-reaction to a mistaken public belief that crime is increasing and the justice system is too lenient.
Fortunately, those who dispense justice and advocates of the rights of victims and society have finally had their voices heard, and Parliament has finally acted accordingly. It only remains for the Senate to do the same.
Improvements have been made and will continue to be made in the justice system. They include stronger firearms control, as well as the proposed rape shield law which is to be brought before this House. Also there is the drug strategy which is ongoing. I understand my friend from Scarborough-Rouge River discussed crack-houses. That certainly is something that must be considered in the justice area.
We have difficulties but we cannot allow them to darken our viewpoint and think that we are not going to be successful in this province and in this country. We are
going to be successful. There are many things that we can look forward to.
For my particular community the free trade agreement will provide opportunities that will be available in that community. We cannot turn our back on it and say that we do not want to have free trade in this globalized economy.
It is interesting that the NDP say that it wants to have none of it, that it wants to abrogate the free trade agreement. The opposite of the free trade agreement is tariff barriers around this country, tariff barriers around a country of 27 million people. That is not a sufficient market. It was at one time. It was during Macdonald's era and so on. It is not sufficient.
If we want to build tariff barriers around the country and throw a dispute resolution mechanism aside we do it at our peril. It has been negotiated so that we have access to the U.S. market and we have a dispute resolution mechanism. We do not want to return to tariff barriers. We do not want to return to a trade war.
Go to GATT.

The member says go to GATT. That was the argument that was used during the election campaign. What has happened? We have not been able to reach a resolution at GATT.
What were we going to do? Were we going to just sit there and not do anything? Were we going to allow ourselves to just be dependent on GATT with our largest trading partner? Could the House imagine what would happen to this country? Could the House imagine how bad this recession would be now if we did not have the free trade agreement?
I am glad that the Liberals have finally seen the light, reversed their 1988 position and said that they are going to support the free trade agreement with negotiations. We are waiting to see what they want to change. However, do not throw away the one opportunity that we have to make this country better. Do not depend on GATT. We have seen that. We are going to try to negotiate it but do not depend on it, because it is not coming about. We certainly hope it will but it has not at this point in time.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I shall try again later.
I am pleased that at long last I am being given the opportunity to correct what I believe is a gross injustice in law. That gross injustice is the application of the goods and services tax on books and reading materials. It is an absolutely insensitive measure on the part of govern-

Private Members' Business
ment. I would hope that we could set partisan politics aside and look at this in an objective and open way.
It is a bad policy. It is contraty to fundamental, basic, democratic principles. This country has never had such a tax and most western countries do not have one. In fact Ireland tried it and the sales dropped so dramatically that it had the good common sense to remove it immediately. It is not only a bad policy, it is also extremely bad for business. There have been loss of jobs and loss of sales. We have demoralized our creative Canadians, those who write and create for a living, and we have picked on students who are very often those who need the most help. Some students in fact would not mind paying a tax I suppose if that money were returned to the coffers, but if you add that to the reductions in transfer payments, they are really very unhappy about what is happening.
It is a bad policy, it is bad for business, and I shall explore those areas with my colleagues, but it is also bad government.
It is bad government because I have received, and so have my colleagues, thousands of petitions asking the government to remove this undemocratic tax on books and reading materials. I went to an internal committee to see whether or not this could be made a votable item. I respected every single criteria which was before me. Yet the committee did not have the courage to make it a votable item.
I have requested a second time just now and I have been refused. How in the world could one consider that good government?
I am sure that Canadians will be extremely interested in what is going to happen here today. I want to remind my colleagues that it was in October 1990 that the Prime Minister indicated there might be some flexibility in this measure. It was in that same month that the then Minister of Finance indicated subsequent to implementation of the tax that there would be an opportunity to review it and to see whether or not it should be eliminated. The time is now. That was 20 months ago. Surely it is now time to look at this.
What has been the impact of that tax? What has been the impact? We can document every single point made here. It has reduced reading in Canada. It has driven
Canadians to shop elsewhere. You have heard about cross-border shopping. It has harmed our writers, our publishers, our bookstores, our libraries and our students.
No doubt it has contributed in its own way to reducing literacy in a country that already has too many functionally illiterate Canadians. That costs the nation over $10 billion per year. It has also contributed to a loss of jobs, many, many jobs. Some publishers are no longer around and some writers can no longer continue.
Let us not kid ourselves. This goods and services tax is a tax on literacy. It is a tax on education, training, retraining, on research and development. It is a tax on learning, knowledge, culture and it is indeed a tax on democracy itself. The goods and services tax is taxing books, magazines and newspapers out of the hands of Canadians.
Let me quote some facts. Book sales dropped 10 per cent the first year of the GST. Subscription response dropped by 50 per cent immediately after the GST. News-stand sales of magazines dropped 10 to 15 per cent last year. The tax on reading has caused the largest drop in Canadian newspaper circulation in 50 years. Circulation dropped 5 per cent last year. Interestingly enough, during the 1981-82 recession, sales dropped by less than 1 per cent in this particular area.
The goods and services tax is driving Canadians out of the country to buy books and magazines. Bookstore sales in some provinces have dropped 20 per cent since the GST was introduced.
U.S. bookstores report that sales to Canadians in certain sectors increased astronomically after January 1, 1991. One store in Vermont now calls itself "Montreal's best English language bookstore", the best English language bookstore, one store in Vermont. You can be proud of that if you want to, but I am not.
The GST is taking books, magazines and newspapers out of Canadian libraries. The rebates to those institutions have taken up to six months. When the rebates come back, do they go back to the libraries? Of course not. They go back to the general revenues. Why do they go back to the general revenues? Because of the reductions in transfer payments, the offloading. Of course
June 5, 1992

they feel that they need those revenues. So the libraries are losing those particular rebates in almost all instances.
What is extremely sad as well, quite apart from the astronomical increases in virtually every sector, the GST is silencing Canadian voices. It is a tax on creativity. It is a tax on culture. It is a tax on a fragile industry that is in peril. That is what the government has not understood. The GST gives a 7 per cent advantage to American magazines. A 7 per cent advantage. Tell any business person that they can have a 7 per cent advantage on a competitor and see what they do. They will take advantage of it.
I am told that there are more than 3,000 U.S. magazines that do not charge the GST on subscriptions.
The government cannot even try to collect it. At least 50 million magazines crossed into Canada tax free last year to compete directly with Canadian magazines on which the GST is paid.
The GST also gives a 7 per cent advantage to American books. Books imported by mail are tax free if they cost less than $20.

Forty dollars? Thank you. My colleague has corrected me. There has been a change now. It is even better for the Americans and harder for Canadians.
The only major Canadian book club has closed since the GST was introduced. Surely no one is proud of that. The GST stops Canadians from getting the books and magazines they want. Some companies refuse to send books to Canada because of the additional burden.
Others have jacked up the prices so high that we can no longer afford them. These are the results of the goods and services tax on books. The tax on reading is an expensive nightmare to administer. Very often it cannot be collected and when it is collected, it can cost up to $100 per collection, probably not worth the time or the effort.
The GST is isolating Canada from the world. Let me give an example. Book collectors are buying outside the country to avoid the tax. Some foreign dealers refuse to trade with Canada. One Canadian rare book dealer reports that sales have dropped 35 per cent since 1990.

During the last recession, sales in this sector grew. As I indicated initially, many countries have refused to tax reading. I want to repeat again. Most western countries do not tax reading. It is seen as a regressive measure, as an insensitive measure, as a measure that goes contrary to basic fundamental human rights and principles.
In our country where we supposedly place a priority on competitiveness, on productivity, on creating a learning culture, clearly this goods and services tax on books and reading materials is inappropriate.
I had indicated that Ireland had tried the tax, and it was smart enough to remove it.

I wish this government could muster the same flexibility and political will, instead of just letting things happen and providing all kinds of arguments I certainly have no intention of supporting.

The GST may only be the beginning. You have heard about the harmonization of the tax with provincial sales taxes. If there is a GST tax on books and reading materials-there is because that is what we are discussing today-and if it is harmonized with the provincial system, then why in the world would there not be an additional tax imposed by the provinces?
I challenge my colleagues to get up and make a guarantee to Canadians that that will not happen.
My colleagues will know as well that we have received thousands of petitions from all over the country, from all socio-economic groups, from all backgrounds who have asked that this undemocratic, insensitive tax that has never been imposed in Canada before be removed immediately because it is contrary to the supposed goals of government: increased and enhanced productivity, more competitiveness and creation of the learning culture.
What does it do? It ignores these petitions. I assure my colleagues, and I would be delighted to table them if they want, that this is but a small sample. Talon Books from Vancouver, B.C. has written a long letter, but I shall quote but one phrase:
I cannot express to you how important this issue remains to book
publishers, book readers and students in Canada.

Oolichan Books from British Columbia also wrote in support of the removal of this tax which it sees as regressive.

We deeply believe, as do the majority of Canadians, that written or educational materials should not be taxed.
We cannot afford to penalize reading and learning in Canada.
"fixing written materials not only discourages reading, it also discourages foreign publishers from exporting to Canadian distributors, penalizes Canadian publishers and distributors through increased operating costs and import prices, and restricts Canadians' access to and selection of books for their use-

"A dark day for Canada! You can count on our support. The GST is inhuman! How could anyone even think of making a case for a tax on reading, as if the revenue it produces could make up for the harm done to freedom of access to the written word!"
An author wrote not long ago: "Books are a gift from the dead to the living to help them live their lives." Need I say more?

I have two others. One is from my constituent, Mrs. Hart, who said: "I sure hope that you have success in getting the GST off books. It is disgusting to have this tax on reading materials". Ladies and gentlemen, I think I have made a very clear case for the immediate removal of the GST on books and other learning materials. It is brutal, and it puts a tremendous burden on the industry and on all levels of society in this country. It also contradicts the basic principles of our society, as well as the government's so-called priorities, which are to increase productivity, make us more competitive and create a learning culture. Well, you do not create a learning culture, and you certainly are not going to motivate people with taxes like these.
