Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise on this debate as someone who as a member of the finance committee participated rather extensively in the hearings across Canada when the GST legislation was introduced in this House.
I note the explanatory note in the particular bill introduced by the member for St. Boniface says:
The purpose of this bill is to exempt books from the application of the goods and services tax.
That is fine for the explanation, but if we look at the actual clause to be inserted in the bill it says:
The supply of any book, paper, record, tape or other document published by a publisher.
I presume that not only includes written books but all tapes, records and videos: everything that has anything to do with the recording industry and movie industry. The list would be rather extensive. It is with that in mind I want to make my particular comments.
During the member's presentation he talked about what other countries have done. He referenced Ireland, and I will presume the information he provided on that country is correct. It is interesting in his presentation he would lead us to believe that literacy has in fact been reduced because of the implementation of the GST.
Most countries involved in the Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development have this kind of tax and in fact tax books. Two countries, Sweden and Denmark, have a value added tax of 20 per cent on books and reading materials. I might point out that neither one of those two countries is known for its high illiteracy rates. In fact probably the opposite is true.
He also suggested several other things relating to the impact of the tax on the cost of books, on students and so on. The member should be aware there are no GST charges applicable on such things as tuition fees or
Private Members' Business
entrance fees to universities or educational institutions. Libraries, schools and universities-I did not hear him mention any one of those three-qualify for a rebate of the GST. The GST has no impact on their cost greater than the existing cost that occurred when the old federal sales tax was in place. This argument that those institutions have somehow seen an added cost is erroneous, to say the least.
I want to comment further. In his presentation he used the word exempt. If one is at all familiar with the legislation, one has to understand that to make a category or a product exempt increases the cost of the product. I realize that is a difficult term, but let us put it this way. All the inputs related to the production of a book, a tape, a magazine or whatever, are produced by business. Businesses qualify for a rebate of all GST they pay on their inputs. The cost of paper they buy and the cost of services they buy, such as telephone, transportation, printing and typesetting, qualify for GST at the present time but at the end of the day they get the GST back.
Under this proposed bill the businesses would not qualify for a rebate of the GST. They would have to absorb that into their costs of operation effectively raising the price, raising the cost of production of all these things to which the member referred. Putting somebody in an exempt category is probably the worst place.
All we need to do is ask the insurance industry, the doctors and other members of the medical profession whether they like being considered exempt. We will not find one that likes being there because effectively it has increased their costs. This bill is proposing to increase the cost to the very industry this member is complaining is under special pressure.
I am not going to debate whether it is under special pressure, but part of the argument the member uses is that people are not prepared to ship books into Canada because of the added burden of the paperwork. That seems to be a real plus for the Canadian book industry. If the industry in the United States is not prepared to send books into Canada because of the paper burden-and I will accept the argument as it was put-the Canadian industry is at an advantage. The U.S. industry is not prepared to participate in shipping products into Canada. Conversely the GST has been good for the Canadian industry, using the very argument the member makes.

June 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
He says that competition does not want to come to Canada.
Let us go back to the exempt status for which he asked. One of the things we faced in our deliberations across Canada was the idea of compliance, the rules on how businesses would implement the GST, how they would sell their products, and how the government would refund the GST to them.
We can just imagine that across the country there are all kinds of small variety stores. Literally everything they sell is taxable under the GST proposal. There are many small gift shops, books stores and department stores. Let us just think where we can buy a magazine, a book, a tape or a film. What they would have to do is segregate their sales. They would have to list all sales that are taxable and keep separate records of all sales that are now exempt under this member's system.
They have to do that now.
I would argue with the member for Broadview-Greenwood. The store that sells 100 per cent taxable items needs to keep no records. At the end of the month it is simply that everything sold is taxable.
What store is that?

I can mention all kinds of stores. The member should go over to Eaton's and ask what it sells or go into K-Mart and ask what it sells. He has just to travel this country to see that there are thousands and thousands of gift shops where everything they sell is taxable. He asked: "What store?" There is no shortage of them anywhere in this country.
Everything in the particular store he walks by at the airport as he goes to fly home is taxable. He is now proposing that what it sells in the way of magazines will not be taxable. He is putting a burden on small business to keep a separate record of what is taxable and what is not taxable.
The donut shops of this country are already complaining because if they sell five donuts they have to charge tax and on six donuts they do not.
That is my point.

Now they have to keep tax records because of that and he is going to say to those donut shops that also sell magazines: "Not only are you going to have to keep tabs when you sell more than six donuts; you are going to have to keep tabs on all the magazines you sell". The donut shops have a problem. With what the member for St. Boniface is proposing, not only would we be placing this problem on the donut shops. We would be placing it on every shop across the country that sells books, magazines, tapes, records, movies and what not.
If I need say nothing else that alone is good enough reason to oppose what the member is recommending in this particular private member's bill. It goes a little further than that.
During the debate that took place on the GST a lot of people came forward and complained about complexity. The simple solution to the complexity problem is to tax everything. There is a substantial group-and I am one of them-that shares the opinion that complexity was required because it was awfully difficult to tax every product that exists in this country. There was a trade-off and in making trade-offs we have to make some decisions. The decision was that books, magazines, tapes and all such other things would be taxable.
The alternative exists. If one wants to describe a particular text book, a book that someone may want to buy because it is a valuable education instrument, one gets into the same problem. One does not want those taxed and somebody can legitimately argue the reason for that. However, I suspect there are certain magazines that people think should be taxed much more heavily.
Although the member's bill does not particularly draw a line as to what is taxable and what is not, obviously it would put in place a supposed benefit by eliminating the tax on literally every product that has anything to do with recording information.
I would say that the tax was fundamentally correct. There are mechanisms to make sure that those who have difficulties at the low end of the scale, low income Canadians, get back enough through the sales tax credit to be able to afford the magazines and books they want. All in all this private member's bill is one that I simply cannot support.
June 5, 1992

Mr. Speaker, I am really pleased to get an opportunity to stand and debate Bill C-331. I want to congratulate my hon. colleague, the member for St. Boniface, because I think this is a piece of legislation that is long overdue.
The fact is that the government's imposition of the GST which has been in place for some time now has amounted to an unfair tax on literacy.
In Canada, approximately 30 per cent of our adult population is functionally illiterate. The worst thing that this government could have done is to bring in a tax on reading which amounts to a tax on literacy in this country.
As a result of the imposition of this tax, the publishing industry has been hit extremely hard. Revenues in the industry have plummeted, partly because of the GST as I mentioned and also partly because of this government's made-in-Canada recession that we have been battling for some time now.
Across this country we have seen publishers reporting revenues down some 20 per cent this year as compared to previous years. That is a significant drop in revenues, much of that because of the imposition of the 7 per cent tax on literacy.
The chair of the Don't Tax Reading Coalition indicated that economists in the tax analysis branch of the Ministry of Finance told her: "They put books and magazines in terms of an increase in price resistance on the part of consumers somewhere around one and a half to two times the tax".
What we really are trying to say here if we put it in other words is that a drop in sales will be seen of some one and a half to two times the rate of the tax increase. By the look of the 20 per cent decrease in revenues compared to the 7 per cent increase in tax, we are seeing it is even greater than has been predicted by these economic forecasts.
The government did know at the time it imposed the GST that it would in effect be taxing literacy in this country.
Private Members' Business
I want to add that youth employment, particularly in lower job categories, but for that matter employment in all age categories has not been assisted by this tax on literacy. When we look at youth employment, university students in Canada who are already facing poor employment opportunities and increasing tuition are now faced with the purchase of books costing upward of $100.
It is very seldom in a university course one buys a single book. Often numerous books have to be purchased for a single course. Anyone who has gone to university knows that courses only requiring one textbook are few and far between.
This tax makes it hard on our university students, particularly those having to finance their own education. It is an unfair tax. It is a tax on literacy. It is a tax on opportunity for higher education. It is a tax that should be rescinded.
Countries in all comers of the earth are focusing on the development, the nurturing, and the educational opportunities for their young people. More money is put into schools and education and it forms the basis for a growing fertile mind. That is not the case in Canada. Not only does this country not put more money into education-in fact we see evidence of the federal government withdrawing funds from post-secondary education-but now it also taxes these growing young minds by taxing that which those minds need to grow in the first place and that is the tax on literature and books.
Over a year ago, the Prime Minister mused publicly that this government would reconsider the wisdom of the imposition of the GST on books. In the throne speech last year, I might remind everyone, he gave his commitment to developing a learning culture to enhance Canadian literacy. Yet this same government has refused to entertain the rescinding of this punitive tax on literature and literacy.
The government instead gave the publishing industry a $140 million boost. At the same time it has overtaxed the consumers of the products these industries produce. I would say in terms of this question the government has been anything but consistent.
The book industry is still appealing to this government to repeal the tax. Canadians who buy books just to enjoy them are leaving those books on the shelves because they are getting more and more expensive. The imposi-

June 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
tion of this 7 per cent increase in price has had a substantial effect on the purchase of those materials.
Canadians are cross-border shopping more and more. They are buying books and magazines south of the border because in the United States the cost is lower.
This government has placed Canada in the unenviable position of being one of the very few English-speaking countries in the world to impose a sales tax on reading materials and books for education. Some countries like Ireland tried it, but it quickly realized its mistake and at least had the courage to admit the mistake and rescind the tax. This government has not recognized the mistake. I suspect even if it has, it does not have the courage to do something about it.
The $140 million subsidy to the publishing industry was needed. It is recognized that it was needed, but it is not nearly enough for an industry that has been virtually sold out by this government with the imposition of this punitive tax on literacy.
The Baie Comeau policy which would have strengthened the Canadian publishing industry was simply ignored by this government. This new program, the $140 million fund for book publishing, will not be effective unless it is enforced with vigour.
I would submit that much can be done to assist the book publishing industry in this country. Much can be done to assist the learning culture in this country, and much can be done to assist the opportunity for education for our young people in this country by rescinding this tax.
The government should recognize it made a serious error in taxing literacy. It should have the courage to admit it made a mistake and it should have the courage to rescind its legislation. Yes, it should have the courage to accept the current bill that is before this House and to proceed with that bill.
It is time that this government withdrew the 7 per cent goods and services tax from books and literature and gave the booksellers and publishers in Canada a break. The industry needs more than the token relief that has been proposed.
This is a good piece of legislation. I congratulate my Liberal colleague for introducing it. I would ask that this House consider granting unanimous consent that the bill
be now read a second time and moved immediately to a legislative committee.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the opportunity this afternoon to speak on this very important issue. First, I want to congratulate the hon. member for St. Boniface for his foresight in bringing this matter to our attention. Need I remind the House that the member for St. Boniface is an educator. He obviously knows quite a bit about this subject, far more than many of us in this House. He is also a former deputy minister of education. He is a tenure professor at a university as well. He probably has a number of other credentials that this House should know about as well but I will not be describing them this afternoon because I want to get on with describing the bill that our colleague proposes.
The member for St. Boniface very astutely pointed out earlier to us today that the bill in question seeks to correct an injustice, one that other governments elsewhere in the world have corrected.
The hon. member from Winnipeg across the way will no doubt be aware that it was none other than the Prime Minister who promised in a speech that this whole business of taxing books would be examined again.
I would certainly not want to contradict the Prime Minister. I would never want to contradict the Prime Minister, but what I want to do now, and what my colleague wants to do, is take the Prime Minister up on his offer. We want to remove the tax on books, as the Prime Minister wants it.
Perhaps some members across the way will contradict the Prime Minister, but certainly not I or the member for St. Boniface because of our tremendous respect for the Prime Minister. We want to remove the GST on books, as the Prime Minister promised that he would.
My colleague from St. Boniface has talked about the loss of jobs in the Canadian book publishing industry, the Canadian magazine and periodical industry and so on. He is obviously quite right. I want to touch on an issue that has been raised in a peripheral way earlier today, but
June 5, 1992

one which I had been involved in. That is the whole issue of cross-border shopping, because many books are purchased that way.
There were not that many a number of years ago. I suppose we could argue that there were always too many because books are unfortunately shipped in great portions into this country compared to what we can export elsewhere. It is an unfortunate thing but it is going from bad to worse.
Many Canadians are members of book clubs, and some of these book clubs are based outside the country. There used to be a situation in which whatever you bought outside the country you had to pay customs on whenever it entered Canada. However, some four or five years ago the government exempted every purchase coming from outside the country so long as it was coming by mail and it was under $40 from all duties and taxes. That meant that someone could take a large padded shipping envelope and fill it up with books, or whatever number of books you could put in it as long as it totalled less than $40, and send it to a client in Canada.
If the client in Canada purchased $75 worth of books you just divided the books as evenly as you could between two bags and shipped two bags into Canada.
Or three or four.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Or whatever the number is, as my colleague from St. Boniface says. Three or four or whatever the number.
That loophole was in itself a disincentive for Canadians to buy books at home and an incentive to buy them elsewhere.
When the GST was added on top of that, there were two reasons to buy books outside of Canada. There was an exemption from whatever duties there might have been and also an exemption from GST. As you do not pay the GST there is no mechanism for the province to collect the provincial sales tax. However, in any case, I do not know of a province that has a provincial sales tax on books. Nevertheless, there was no way to collect that tax if a province were to have so chosen.
In any case, the GST does apply on books, and it and any duty is not collected.
Private Members' Business
The government now says: "We will fix that because we will now charge the GST and anything else that is applicable on purchases of $20". It has proposed a bill that is at report stage. It should be debated within the next week or so.
Nevertheless someone can still buy a book, or several books, for $19.90 and ship the order into Canada in various packages of $19.90. The government has now applied a $5 surcharge on every purchase coming into Canada by mail. It is an administration fee by the post office and that is not bad in itself, except that the U.S. post office charges roughly $10 in a similar situation.
It charges $8.40 U.S. which is roughly $10 Canadian. Actually, it is about $10.50 with the present value of our currency. If the Canadian government wanted to apply reciprocal rules why did it charge $5 instead of $10? If it really was serious about curtailing cross-border shopping of many goods, including books, it could at the very least have imposed similar fees.

So, Mr. Speaker, in the few minutes remaining to me, I would like to emphasize that this initiative is a bad policy and undemocratic. Of course it is bad for the book publishing industry, for editors and those who publish Canadian books. It creates more unemployment, as if we did not have enough already.
The government does not listen to Canadians, especially since, need I remind hon. members opposite, as I said somewhat jokingly a little earlier, the Prime Minister himself promised a group of Canadians a while ago to review this whole policy of collecting the GST on books. If the Prime Minister was serious then, I think he should take the opportunity in the next few minutes to telephone the members opposite in the lobby and remind them that he made the promise. The hon. member for St. Boniface did not promise Canadians that the GST would not apply to books, neither did the member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell; the Prime Minister himself did. The member for Winnipeg sitting opposite should remember. I am sorry if I interrupt her to remind her of this fact, but she should know that.

Private Members' Business

The member for Ontario should know that as well, because I am sure the member for Ontario was aware that the Prime Minister made that promise. Both he and his colleague from Winnipeg sitting across the way, who are preparing right now presumably to destroy this good piece of legislation, should know that what my colleague has proposed is a mechanism to achieve that which the Prime Minister himself promised to Canadians.
If promises of the Prime Minister mean anything-
Be more accurate.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, could you imagine Tories asking others to be more accurate? The Prime Minister told Canadians that he would look at this issue. If the member across is convinced of what he is saying then let this bill proceed to committee. Let him and any others who still want that tax speak before the parliamentary committee that will deal with it.
If his argument has any sense at all he can make it before all the parliamentarians on the committee. I will make a prediction that the hon. member and others would not risk that. Instead, it is gong to be easier to kill the bill on the floor of the House of Commons than to muster up the intestinal fortitude necessary to defend the policy before one's colleagues in a parliamentary committee. That is the sad reality that we are faced with this afternoon. It is easier to kill the promise of the Prime Minister on the floor of the House than trying instead to defend what it is that the Conservative members are saying they will defend before a parliamentary committee.
We will see in a few minutes just where the strength is of those members. They could right now agree to the motion that my colleague moved earlier today to refer this issue to a parliamentary committee and to study it. They will hear the witnesses from the book publishing industry. They have that opportunity. They have that power this afternoon. They have the full authority to do that. Let us see.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Dorothy Dobbie (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a great deal of respect for my hon. colleague across the way whose bill we are debating this afternoon. I know that he is an educator and a person with a great deal of concern for people in general and particularly for students.
I want to ask him something before I launch into the rest of my remarks. Perhaps he could cogitate over this. How would he differentiate between what is educational and what is entertainment? Would he exempt from tax such publications as Penthouse or perhaps commercial catalogues. Those are all books and things that people read. Would he exempt from taxation music or adult videos which are educational tools? Videos are educational tools, but some of them perhaps are not educating people in the way that the hon. member has intended in his bill.
There are complications that I would like him to think about. I do not think that he wants us to exempt Sports Illustrated for example from the GST. I think he should think about those things.
We all know that the GST replaced a very destructive tax. It was 13.5 per cent and we all remember those days. When I was the president of the chamber of commerce and in business, business people came before us all of the time saying: "Get rid of this pernicious, underground, hidden tax on manufacturers". At the time that the tax was rescinded and the GST was put in place, it was 13.5 per cent. It was called the silent killer of jobs and there was good reason for that because indeed that is precisely what it did.
The GST actually replaced something that Canadians had been asking for a long time to be replaced with a 7 per cent tax. It is a point of sales tax on a broad base and it is a much fairer way of providing much needed revenues for all of the programs and services that we want in this country. One of these things in particular is education. My hon. colleague across the way would agree that this is a very worth-while activity for governments to engage in funding.
There are exemptions of course to this value-added tax that we put in place to replace the 13.5 per cent manufacturers' sales tax and they are important exemptions. These are exemptions that occur for residential rents for example, and prescription drugs and day care

services. None of these things have the GST applied to them.
In addition to that we have done more. There is a refundable GST credit for families that are earning under $30,000 a year. These are low and modest income families. This credit makes many of those families better off now than they were before the GST was imposed. All of these measures are very helpful to making sure that Canadians on low and modest incomes can access all of the books that they need in order to improve their education.
I think that even the members on the other side of the House will recognize that the GST is a modem and efficient way of raising funds that are needed by governments in order to carry on the business of government and to provide the kind of services that my hon. friend across the way-and the hon. member for Glengarry- Prescott-Russell who has just spoken-will recognize as being things that they themselves taught Canadians to expect.
Certainly we have to find the funds now to pay for these things. The GST is a fair way of doing this.
Of the world's most highly industrialized economies, members of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, 19 out of 24 countries rely on a value-added tax system in order to do the same things we want to do. That is to have a fair system, one that is modern and meets the needs of a modem world.
Hon. members know that Canada is just one of 48 countries, among them Sweden, Germany, even Japan, which have a value-added tax system. They have come to realize that this is a reasonable way of raising the revenues required to carry on business.
We have to recognize that this is a new world. This is a global community that we live in now, a borderless world. It is no longer possible to live in economic isolation. We can no longer have internal policies and programs that separate us from the the world economy. Therefore, we would not want Canada to fall out of step with those major competitors we have in the rest of the world.
This tax is part of that. This is part of a comprehensive measure that the government has in place to modernize Canada's economy, to make us more competitive so that in the long run, Canadians will be more prosperous.
Private Members' Business
Canadians will be more highly educated because they will have access to more educational materials, including books. This is just one of the measures which will make it possible for Canadians to realize the full potential of the wealth that exists in this country in a more fair and even-handed way.
The GST is undoubtedly the key to strengthening Canada's economy and to working out the fiscal problems which have occurred and grown over the past two or three decades as we taught Canadians to expect more and more from their government.
It is just one of the programs that we have created to try and produce a better standard of living for all of us. Since 1984, we have introduced many measures that would really enhance our economic viability in this country. Even my hon. colleagues would acknowledge that the GST is a more fair and sensible tax. I saw them vote in favour the other day of keeping this intact.
The GST has removed a tax burden from Canadian businesses that is enabling them to become more efficient. I might say that because the federal sales tax was levied at the manufacturers' level, even books suffered to some degree from the underground effects of that tax. If manufacturing equipment was bought on which to print books, federal sales tax and provincial sales tax were paid on that equipment. Or it was paid on inks or on hand cleaners, depending on what was being done. So there was a component of the tax in publications.
In addition to that, it is true that there may be an emotional appeal to removing the GST from books. But as I began by saying, it is an administrative nightmare to try and make a subjective judgment on what is educational and what is not, what should be taxed and what should not.
I believe that most Canadians would not want to see publications like Penthouse magazine or Sports Illustrated exempt from the GST or commercial catalogues exempt from the GST.
The government has put a system in place that gives lower income and modest income Canadians some additional funds to cover the cost added to the price of a book because of the GST. It has done something, and $140 million is quite something, to support the publishing industry in order to keep the cost of books down.

June 5, 1992
Private Members' Business
In order to make sure that people who are in the business of producing books are competitive and that we produce the kinds of books Canadians want to read, we want to reduce the burden of the administration of the tax such as the GST.
My colleagues across the way would agree with us when we say that we support literacy. The GST is not a literacy issue. We have done everything that we can to alleviate any of the possibility of adverse effects of the GST. We all support literacy and the GST is a fair way to raise funds for the future prosperity of our nation.
